biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: evolutionary diversification of species derived from a common ancestor into a variety of ecological roles.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: adaptive radiation

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: any species, strain or biotype of plant, animal or pathogenic agent injurious to plants or other organisms and/or their products. [JVG]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: pest

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: is transfer that completely eliminates any adverse effect on the conservation and sustainable use of biological diversity. [BSWG/2/5: Draft Biosafety Protocol to the Convention on Biological Diversity, prepared by the Community Nutrition Institute, 910 17th Street NW, Suite 413, Washington, DC 20006]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: safe transfer

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a particular type of environment requiring unique adaptations then allowing adaptive radiation to occur.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: adaptive zone

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a major food-source in a variety of ecosystems, consisting of organic remains of plants and animals, often heavily colonised by bacteria.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: detritus

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: an international celebration of science and humanity. Darwin Day, February 12.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: Darwin Day

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the breaking up of extensive landscape features into disjunct, isolated, or semi-isolated patches as a result of land-use changes.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: fragmentation

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: one or more officials who are empowered to represent and negotiate on behalf of their government
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: national delegation

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a formal agreement of the Conference of the Parties to the CBD that leads to binding actions. It becomes part of the agreed body of decisions by the Conference of the Parties that direct the future work of the Conference of the Parties and guide action at the national level. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: decision of the Conference of the Parties
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.objecttrans_en: decision of the Conference of the Parties
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.objectname_en: decision of the conference of the parties

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the science of conserving biological diversity.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: conservation biology

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: taking place in a living organism.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: in vivo

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the storage of plant material at very low temperatures (-196°C) in liquid nitrogen. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: cryopreservation

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: goods that provide a flow of services over time.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: assets

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: theory that suggests that under natural circumstances, species addition and loss are balanced, and furthermore, that displacement from the equilibrium value results in changes in speciation or extinction rate that tend to restore the system to its equilibrium state. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: equilibrium theory

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: referring to depths between 200 to 1,000 meters in the ocean, seas and lakes.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: mesopelagic

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: ecological resilience can be defined in two ways. The first is a measure of the magnitude of disturbance that can be absorbed before the (eco)system changes its structure by changing the variables and processes that control behaviour. The second, a more traditional meaning, is as a measure of resistance to disturbance and the speed of return to the equilibrium state of an ecosystem. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: ecological or ecosystem resilience

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: to facilitate negotiations, the President or the Chair of a meeting may establish smaller drafting groups to meet separately and in private to prepare text. Observers may generally not attend.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: drafting groups

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the sharing of authority, responsibility, and benefits between government and local communities in the management of natural resources. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: co-management

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a process by which water rises from lower depths into the shallows, usually the result of divergence or offshore currents.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: upwelling

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the extinction of one species by another species in the same area through competition.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: competitive exclusion

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the place occupied by a species in its ecosystem and its role: where it lives, what it feeds on and when it performs all its activities.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: niche

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: see: primary forest.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: natural forest

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the value to the private agent of using or refraining from using a resource. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: private value

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a group of individuals with common ancestry that are much more likely to mate with one another than with individuals from another such group.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: population

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the value of knowing that a particular species, habitat or ecosystem does and will continue to exist. It is independent of any use that the valuer may make of the resource. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: existence value

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: an ecosystem in which a river or stream meets ocean waters; characterised by intermediate or variable salinity levels and often by high productivity.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: estuary

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the process of division of sexual cells in which the number of chromosomes in each nucleus is reduced to half the normal number found in normal somatic cells. When two sexual cells fuse, each contributes its half of the chromosomes. The resulting embryo contains the full chromosome complement. Cells with half the chromosomes are called haploids: those with the normal chromosomal complement, diploids. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: meiosis

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: external costs/benefits exist when an activity by one person causes a gain/loss of welfare to another person that is uncompensated within the market. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: external costs/externalities

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a sample of a crop variety collected at a specific location and time; may be of any size. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: accession

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: all conservation of genetic material in vivo, but out of the environment in which it developed, and in vitro including, inter alia, the cryoconservation of semen, oocytes, embryos, cells or tissues. Note that ex situ conservation and ex situ preservation are considered here to be synonymous. [FAO]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: ex situ conservation of farm animal genetic diversity
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.objecttrans_en: ex situ conservation of farm animal genetic diversity
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.objectname_en: ex situ conservation of farm animal genetic diversity

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: application of phytosanitary [and other] measures to eliminate a pest from an area [FAO bis]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: eradication

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: any of a class of nitrogenous compounds forming an essential part of living organisms and having large molecules consisting of one or more chains of amino acids linked together. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: protein

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the use of ecological concepts and principles to study, design, and manage agricultural systems. Agroecology seeks to evaluate the full effect of system inputs and outputs by integrating cultural and environmental factors into the analysis of food production systems and to use this knowledge to improve these systems, taking into account the needs of both the ecosystem as a whole and the people within it. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: agroecology

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: material lacking the characteristics or agronomic performance for cropping in a specific area. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: unadapted

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: roundworms, often internal parasites of animals and plants. The latter are significant economic pests on foodcrops as few crops are immune to attacks of these creatures which inhabit the soil about the roots of plants. The development of nematode-resistant varieties of crop plants is important to food growth economics. [CUB, modified by JVG]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: nematode

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - the attachment of monetary value to an object through a consideration of both internalised and externalised costs. - this is a method for determining the importance of environmental consequences of economic activity that are not taken into account in market transactions. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: valuation

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: elected by the Parties to preside over the COP, the President is often a senior official or minister from the state or region hosting the meeting.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: President

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: bioprospecting regarded as the perpetuation of the colonial habit of plundering other countries' biological resources without fair and equitable compensation, resulting in environmental, economic and social detriment  (ref.: K. ten Kate, 1995. Biopiracy or Green Petroleum? Expectations & Best Practice in Bioprospecting. - Overseas Development Administration, Environment Policy Department, London).
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: biopiracy

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: an abstract representation of the feeding relationships of organisms within a community or an ecosystem. [JVG]fouling communities
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: food web

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the principle that international shipment of a pesticide that is banned or severely restricted in order to protect human health or the environment should not proceed without agreement, where such agreement exists, or contrary to the decision of the designated national authority in the participating importing country. [BSWG/2/5: FAO International Code of Conduct on the Distribution and Use of Pesticides] MOSAICC defines the term 'prior informed consent' as follows: - the consent is to be acquired prior to accessing microbial genetic resources (MGRs), - the consent is to be based on legally correct and trustworthy information provided by the partners to this PIC-agreement, - the consent is to be granted by a competent authority of the country providing the MGRs and according to the national legislation and procedures. The PIC is provided by competent authorities that are entitled to provide the authorization for access to MGRs. For the purpose of MOSAICC these competent authorities will be called 'PIC-authorities'. More information: Philippe Desmeth, BCCMtm International Co-operation Officer. PIC is a procedure that helps participating countries learn more about the characteristics of potentially hazardous chemicals that may be shipped to them, initiates a decision making process on the future import of these chemicals by the countries themselves and facilitates the dissemination of this decision to other countries. The aim is to promote a shared responsibility between exporting and importing countries in protecting human health and the environment from the harmful effects of certain hazardous chemicals being traded internationally.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: prior informed consent (PIC)

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: suggests that the number of species increases or decreases depending on how the environment influences species production, exchange and extinction at any particular time.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: theory of local existence

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: is the amount of compensation an individual is willing to take in exchange for giving up some good or service. This may be elicited from stated or revealed preference approaches. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: willingness to accept

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: see: genetic drift.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: drift

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: is a synonym of biological diversity, see below. The contracted form 'biodiversity' was apparently coined by W.G. Rosen (1985) for the first planning meeting of the 'National Forum on Biodiversity' held in Washington DC (September 1986), the proceedings of which (E.O. Wilson and F.M. Peter, 1988) brought the notion of biodiversity to the attention of a wide field of scientists and others. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: biodiversity

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the loss of genetic diversity when a new colony is formed (e.g. on an oceanic island) by a very small number of individuals from a larger population elsewhere. [JVG]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: founder effect

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the conditions determined with reasonable certainty to have acceptable or negligible risk to human health or to managed or natural ecosystems. [BSWG/2/5: Proposed USDA Guidelines for Research Involving the Planned Introduction in the Environment of Organisms with Deliberate modified Hereditary Traits, US Department of Agriculture, 56 FR 4134, 1 February 1991]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: safe or safety

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the return of an ecosystem or habitat to its original community structure, natural complement of species, and natural functions.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: restoration

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the use of biotechnological methods to grow large numbers of plants from very small pieces of plants, often from single cells using tissue culture methods. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: micropropagation

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: management approach whereby a specific area is zoned and regulated for a variety of uses, including research, species protection, tourism, harvesting, cutting down trees, hunting, or fishing, that is compatible with the management goals for the area.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: integrated area management  (IAM)

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a branch of economics that takes account of ecological principles and examines economic values of non-market ecological products and services.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: ecological economics

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: microscopic dinoflagellate algae that live mutualistically in the tissues of certain marine invertebrates, including reef-building corals and giant clams.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: zooxanthellae

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the surveying, sorting, cataloguing, quantifying and mapping of entities such as genes, individuals, populations, species, habitats, ecosystems and landscapes or their components, and the synthesis of the resulting information for the analysis of process. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: inventorying

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a group of viruses whose hosts are specifically bacteria. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: bacteriophages

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the management of human interactions with genes, species, and ecosystems so as to provide the maximum benefit to the present generation while maintaining their potential to meet the needs and aspirations of future generations; encompasses elements of saving, studying, and using biodiversity. [WRI et al.]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: conservation of biodiversity

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a state of low oxygen concentration in water and sediments, relative to the needs of most aerobic species.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: hypoxia

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: staffed by international civil servants and responsible for servicing the Conference of the Parties and ensuring its smooth operation, the Secretariat to the Convention on Biological Diversity makes arrangements for meetings, compiles and prepares reports, communicates with the Convention Parties, and co-ordinates with other relevant international bodies. The Secretariat to the Convention on Biological Diversity is administered by UNEP and located in Montreal, Canada. [JVG]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: Secretariat to the Convention on Biological Diversity
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.objecttrans_en: Secretariat to the Convention on Biological Diversity
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.objectname_en: secretariat to the convention on biological diversity

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: selection favouring individuals that deviate in either direction from the population average. Selection favours individuals that are larger or smaller than average. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: disruptive selection

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a community of salt-tolerant trees, with associated shrubs or vines and other organisms, that grows in a zone roughly coinciding with the intertidal zone along protected tropical and subtropical coasts.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: mangrove forest

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: Genetic Use Restriction Technologies; see Terminator technology and Traitor technology
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: GURTs

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: originally used in the business sector, a clearing-house is a service which facilitates and simplifies transactions among multiple parties. [JVG]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: clearing-house

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the management of a specific resource (such as a forest or pasture) by a well defined group of resource users with the authority to regulate its use by members and outsiders. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: common property resource management

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: occurs when government policies do not correct for market failures. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: policy failure

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the scientific study of the geographic distribution of organisms.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: biogeography

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a term applied to pollutants which are not biodegradable or are only biodegradable with difficulty. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: recalcitrant

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a process by which surface waters increase in density and sink. Strong downwelling occurs mainly off Greenland and Antarctica.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: downwelling

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: see: precautionary principle.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: do-no-harm principle

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the multi-billion-dollar GEF was established by the World Bank, UNDP and UNEP in 1990. It operates the Convention's 'financial mechanism' on an interim basis and funds developing-country projects that have global biodiversity benefits. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: Global Environment Facility (GEF)

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: speciation through geographically separated populations.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: allopatric speciation

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - storage of living materials as tissue culture, and may include cryopreservation (storage at low temperature, usually in liquid nitrogen). - literally 'in glass'. Experimental reproduction of biological processes in isolation from a living organism, e.g. tissue culture. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: in vitro

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: individual organism resulting from a cross between parents of differing genotypes. Hybrids may be fertile or sterile, depending on qualitative and/or quantitative differences in the genomes of the two parents. Hybrids are most commonly formed by sexual cross-fertilization between compatible organisms, but techniques for the production of hybrids from widely differing organisms are being developed by cell fusion and tissue culture. [CUB slightly modified by JVG]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: hybrid

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the model of no effect.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: null model

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the country which possesses those genetic resources in in-situ conditions. [CBD]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: country of origin of genetic resources
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.objecttrans_en: country of origin of genetic resources
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.objectname_en: country of origin of genetic resources

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: an open session of the entire Conference of the Parties or a subsidiary body where all formal decisions are taken.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: plenary

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: seed that can be dried and stored for long periods at reduced temperatures and under low humidity. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: orthodox seed

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: The Manila Declaration Concerning The Ethical Utilization Of Biological Resources, developed at the ASOMPS VII meeting in Manila, Philippines, 2-7 February 1992.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: Manila Declaration

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the unintentional discharge of a microbiological agent (i.e., microorganism or virus) or eukaryotic cell due to a failure in the containment system. [Proposed Action under the Guidelines for Research Involving Recombinant DNA Molecules (51 Federal Register 16958) National Institute of Health 55 FR 53258]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: accidental release

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: used during negotiations in UN meetings to indicate that a section of text is being discussed but has not yet being agreed.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: square brackets

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: because the use of public goods by one person does not exclude others, of each user has an incentive to allow others to pay the cost of the public good. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: free-rider problem of public goods

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the study of the historical evolutionary and genetic relationships among organisms and of their phenotypic similarities and differences.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: systematics

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - a group of animals or plants related by descent from common ancestors and visibly similar in most characteristics. Taxonomically, a species can have numerous breeds. - either a sub specific group of domestic livestock with definable and identifiable external characteristics that enable it to be separated by visual appraisal from other similarly defined groups within the same species or a group for which geographical and / or cultural separation from phenotypically similar groups has led to acceptance of its separate identity. [FAO]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: breed

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - living in the water column. (Opposite: benthic). - free-swimming (nektonic) or floating (planktonic) organisms that live exclusively in the water column, not on the bottom.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: pelagic

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a product produced by chemical reactions in living organisms. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: biochemical

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - the transfer of pollen from an anther to the stigma in angiosperms, or from the microsporangium to the micropyle in gymnosperms. - pollination happens when pollen lands on a female part of a flower such as the stigma of a carpel. Pollination can be caused by pollinators such as butterflies, bees, birds, bats but also by the wind or the water.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: pollination

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: compounds ubiquitous in living organisms and essential for life, such as carbohydrates, the essential amino acids and polymers derived from them. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: primary metabolites

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: variety or multiformity of human social structures, belief systems, and strategies for adapting to situations in different parts of the world. [WRI et al.]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: cultural diversity

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: sales by farmers to other farmers of seed they have saved. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: brown bag sales

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: contain identical linear sequences of genes and pair during meiosis. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: homologous chromosomes

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a planned and managed repository containing animal genetic resources. Repositories include the environment in which the genetic resource has developed, or is now normally found (in situ) or facilities elsewhere (ex situ - in vivo or in vitro). For in vitro, ex situ genome bank facilities, germplasm is stored in the form of one or more of the following: semen, ova, embryos and tissue samples. [FAO]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: cattle milk proteins

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - the functional unit of heredity; the part of the DNA molecule that encodes a single enzyme or structural protein unit. - the unit of heredity transmitted from generation to generation during sexual or asexual reproduction. More generally, the term 'gene' may be used in relation to the transmission and inheritance of particular identifiable traits. [FAO] - the units of heredity transmitted from generation to generation. Each gene is a segment of nucleic acid carried in the DNA encoded for a specific protein. More generally, the term 'gene' may be used in relation to the transmission and inheritance of particular identifiable traits. The basic unit of heredity, a gene is an ordered sequence of nucleotide bases comprising a segment of DNA. A gene contains the sequence of DNA which encodes one polypeptide chain. The sum of an organism's genes is known as its genome. [CUB] The variant forms of each gene are termed alleles.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: gene

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a right enabling an inventor to exclude imitators from the market for a limited time.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: intellectual property right

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a core proposition is that future generations have a right to an inheritance (capital bequest) sufficient to allow them to generate a level of well-being no less than that of the current generation. Fairness in the treatment of different members of the same generation. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: intergenerational equity

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a breeding method aimed at increasing the frequency of favourable genes through repeated cycles of selection and selected crossing of individuals. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: recurrent selection

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: in-session document issued informally to facilitate negotiations; it does not have an official document symbol although they may have an identifying number or the name of the author(s).
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: non-paper

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: energy made available by the combustion of materials derived from biological sources. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: bioenergy

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: plants, animals, fungi, and micro-organisms that occur naturally in a given area or region.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: native species

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - any use of an organism that is not a contained use. [BSWG/2/5: UNEP International Technical Guidelines for Safety in Biotechnology] - introduction into the environment for scientific or commercial purposes of transgenic plants and microorganisms. [BSWG/2/5: FAO Draft International Code of Conduct for Plant Biotechnology as it Affects the Conservation and Utilization of Plant Genetic Resources] - any intentional introduction into the environment of a GMO or a combination of GMOs without provisions for containment such as physical barriers or a combination of physical barriers together with chemical and/or biological barriers used to limit their contact with the general population and the environment. [BSWG/2/5: Council Directive 90/220/EEC on the deliberate release into the environment of genetically modified organisms]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: deliberate release

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: speciation in which the new species forms from a population contiguous with the ancestral species' geographic range.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: parapatric speciation

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: uptake of naked DNA by a competent recipient strain. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: transformation

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a population of organisms that travels between the exclusive economic zones of two or more countries, or between them and the high seas.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: straddling stock

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: small area with uniform biological conditions (climate, soil, altitude, etc.).
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: biotope

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: environments characterised by extremes in growth conditions, including temperature, salinity, pH, and water availability, among others. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: extreme environments

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: movement of organisms away from place of birth.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: dispersal

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a description of the way in which the well-being of individuals depends on different combinations of goods and services consumed. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: utility function

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: pertaining to any aspect of life, especially to characteristics of entire populations or ecosystems.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: biotic

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: evolutionary changes on the small scale, such as changes in gene frequencies within a population.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: microevolution

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - pesticide made from biological sources, that is from toxins which occur naturally. - naturally occurring biological agents used to kill pests by causing specific biological effects rather than by inducing chemical poisoning. The idea is based on mimicking processes that arise naturally (e.g. protecting the coffee bean by its caffeine content), and is argued to be favorable to conventional chemical pesticides as it is more easily biodegradable and more target specific. A pesticide in which the active ingredient is a virus, fungus, or bacteria, or a natural product derived from a plant source. A biopesticide's mechanism of action is based on specific biological effects and not on chemical poisons. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: biopesticide

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - a set of genetically identical organisms, asexually reproduced from one ancestral organism. - a genetic replica of another organism obtained through a non-sexual (no fertilization) reproduction process. Cloning by nucleus transfer involves the transfer of a donor nucleus from (cultured) cells of embryonic, fetal or adult origin into the recipient cytoplasm of an enucleated oocyte or zygote, and the subsequent development of embryos and animals. These clones usually have different mitochondrial genomes. [FAO] - cell or organism identical to an ancestor with respect to genotype and phenotype. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: clone

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the hypothesis that decision-makers base their decisions on predictions which contain no systematic errors.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: rational expectations

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a regional or global oceanic-atmospheric perturbation whose manifestations range from increased sea surface temperatures in the tropical East Pacific to aberrant rainfall patterns.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: El Niño event

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a reactive method of dealing with the environment that places the burden of proof on those who would conserve. (Opposite: the precautionary principle)
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: wait-and-see principle

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a generic term, not specifically definable, but generally applied to a biological control agent, usually a pathogen, formulated and applied in a manner similar to a chemical pesticide, and normally used for the rapid reduction of a pest population for short term pest control [FAO bis]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: biological pesticide (biopesticide)

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the transfer of knowledge or equipment to enable the manufacture of a product, the application of a process, or the rendering of a service. [CUB].
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: technology transfer

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a pollinator is an agent, generally an animal (insect, bird, bat, etc.) that carries pollen to the female part of a flower.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: pollinator

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - cultivation of marine organisms, plant and animal, for purposes of human consumption. - the growing of marine animals and plants under specialized culture conditions. - controlled cultivation of marine organisms in tanks, ponds, cages, rafts, or other structures - farming of marine organisms, including fish, molluscs, crustaceans and plants. [JVG] - breeding and rearing marine fish, shellfish, plants etc. for food in special areas. [JVG]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: mariculture

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - any operation involving organisms which are controlled by physical barriers or a combination of physical and/or biological barriers which limit their contact with, or their impacts on, the potentially receiving environment, which includes humans. [BSWG/2/5: UNEP International Technical Guidelines for Safety in Biotechnology] - any operation in which microorganisms are genetically modified or in which such genetically modified microorganisms are cultured, stored, used, transported, destroyed or disposed of and for which physical barriers, or a combination of physical barriers together with chemical and/or biological barriers are used to limit their contact with the general population and the environment. [BSWG/2/5: Council Directive 90/219/EEC on the contained use of genetically modified microorganisms]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: contained use

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the development of germplasm to a state where it is viable for breeder's use. Primarily involves the evaluation of traits from exotic material and their introduction into more cultivated backgrounds. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: pre-breeding

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the release of a biological control agent into an ecosystem or an area where it did not exist previously. [FAO bis]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: introduction of a biological control agent
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.objecttrans_en: introduction of a biological control agent
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.objectname_en: introduction of a biological control agent

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - floating, drifting or slowly swimming organisms that cannot swim against currents. - floating and drifting organisms that have limited swimming abilities and that are carried largely passively with water currents (opp. nekton). These include bacteria (bacterioplankton), plants and plant-like organisms (phytoplankton) and the animals (zooplankton) that eat them.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: plankton

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: specialised haploid cell (sometimes called a sex cell) whose nucleus and often cytoplasm fuses with that of another gamete in the process of fertilisation field. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: gamete

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a type of plant, plant product or other regulated article being moved for trade or other purpose [FAO bis]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: commodity

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a substance derived from plants; a vegetable drug, especially in its crude state. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: botanical

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: when several taxa are subdivided by the same tectonically and climatically produced barriers to dispersal.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: vicariant patterns

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: an agreement can be adopted by consensus rather than by a vote when there are no stated objections from delegations
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: consensus

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the removal of the entire standing crop of trees. In practice, may refer to exploitation that leaves much unsaleable material standing (e.g. a commercial clear-cutting). [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: clear-cutting

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: government grants to suppliers of goods or services.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: subsidies

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: expansion of the geographical distribution of a pest [or other organism] within an area. [FAO bis]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: spread

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: an organism that produces more of the desired enzyme or compound than normal. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: over-expression host

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: country providing genetic resources.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: source country

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - the implementation of the most appropriate measures to minimize the identified risks and mitigate their effects while achieving the anticipated results. [BSWG/2/5: Report of Panel of Experts on Biosafety] - refers to the ways that appropriate methods are applied in order to minimize risks and should not be determined by and in proportion to the results of the risk/safety analysis. It does not include broader considerations of a political, socio-economic, value and/or ethical nature. [BSWG/2/5: Safety Considerations for Biotechnology Scale-up of Crop Plants OECD 1993] - the measures to ensure that the production and handling of an organism is safe. [BSWG/2/5: UNEP International Technical Guidelines for Safety in Biotechnology]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: risk management

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the act or product of cross-fertilization between different individuals. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: cross

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: use or defense of a resource by one individual that reduces the availability of the resource to other individuals.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: competition

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: an organism having a cell without a distinct nucleus. Bacteria and blue-green algae are prokaryotes. (Opposite: eukaryote.)
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: prokaryote

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the entry of a pest [or species] resulting in its establishment. [FAO bis]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: introduction

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the therapeutic use of pure essential oils and other substances obtained from flowers, plants, and aromatic shrubs, through inhalation and application to the skin. Generally based on traditional practices from around the world. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: aromatherapy

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the return of a habitat to its original community structure, natural complement of species and natural functions.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: habitat restoration

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a sharp increase in density of phytoplankton or benthic algae in a given area.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: bloom

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: ecological or ecosystem processes or functions which have value to individuals or to society. [JVG]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: ecological or ecosystem services

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - mating among related individuals. - mating of close relatives, which reduces genetic diversity, often leading to expression of deleterious recessive characteristics and reduction of fitness in the offspring.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: inbreeding

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: referring to patterns or processes resulting from random factors.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: stochastic

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: characteristic chromosomes of a species.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: karyotype

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: no longer surviving. (Opposite: extant)
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: extinct

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the value of resources which are not diminished by their use. Values that do not require access to or active use of a biological resource by the valuer. Passive use value may imply that the resource is used by other humans whose welfare matters to the valuer. It therefore includes vicarious use value, bequest value and existence value. (Also non-use or passive use value.) [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: non-consumptive value

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a substance or place required by an organism for its growth, maintenance and reproduction.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: resource

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: selection favouring individuals in the middle of the distribution of phenotypes in a population and disfavouring the extremes. Also called normalizing selection.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: stabilizing selection

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: an enzyme, used to catalyze a chemical reaction. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: biocatalyst

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a gill net suspended vertically from floats at a specific depth and left to drift freely.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: driftnet

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a breed where the total number of breeding females is less than 100 or the total number of breeding males is less than or equal to five; or the overall population size is close to, but slightly above 100 and decreasing, and the percentage of pure-bred females is below 80 percent. [FAO]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: critical breed

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: perpetuation, for the foreseeable future of a pest, or a biological agent, within an area after entry [FAO bis]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: establishment

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: these approaches, which include derived demand approaches and indirect valuation methods, infer values from data on behavioural changes in actual markets related in some way to the missing market(s.) [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: revealed preference approach

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - development that meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs. [Earth Summit +5] - development that meets the needs and aspirations of the current generation without compromising the ability to meet those of future generations. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: sustainable development

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the zone of overlap between land and sea that is submerged at high tide and exposed at low tide.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: intertidal zone

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a plant cell from which the cell wall has been removed by mechanical or enzymatic means. Protoplasts can be prepared from primary tissues of most plant organs as well as from cultured plant cells. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: protoplast

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: naturally-occurring compounds found in fruits and vegetables, such as beta carotene, capsaicin, and flavonoids. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: phytonutrients

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - having two sets of genes and two sets of chromosomes - one from the female parent, one from the male parent. - having a pair of homologous chromosomes with the exception of the sex chromosome, the total number of chromosomes being twice that of a gamete. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: diploid

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: established under UNESCO's Man and the Biosphere (MAB) Programme, biosphere reserves are a series of protected areas linked through a global network, intended to demonstrate the relationship between conservation and development. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: biosphere reserve

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: organisms that have undergone domestication.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: domesticates

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a species whose status provides information on the overall condition of the ecosystem and of other species in that ecosystem. They reflect the quality and changes in environmental conditions as well as aspects of community composition. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: indicator species

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: people whose ancestors inhabited a place or country when persons from another culture or ethnic background arrived on the scene and dominated them through conquest, settlement, or other means and who today live more in conformity with their own social, economic, and cultural customs and traditions than with those of the country of which they now form a part. (Also: "native peoples" or "tribal peoples".) [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: indigenous peoples

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: The Leipzig Declaration on conservation and sustainable utilization of plant genetic resources for food and agriculture, Leipzig, 23 June 1996.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: Leipzig Declaration

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: categories where critical or endangered breeds are being maintained by an active public conservation programme or within a commercial or research facility. [FAO]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: critical-maintained breed and endangered-maintained breed

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: organisms living on or in the bottom of oceans, seas, rivers, lakes and other water bodies. [JVG] Depending on the size of the organisms, benthos is regarded as macrobenthos (organisms > 1000 µm), meiobenthos (organisms between 42 µm and 1000 µm) and nanobenthos or microbenthos (organisms < 42 µm). Depending on the depth distribution, benthos is regarded as epibenthos (living between low water line and 200 m depth), mesobenthos (living at depths between 200 and 1000 m), hypobenthos (living between 1000 and 2000 m) and abyssal benthos (living below 2000 m).
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: benthos

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: out of the original location. In conservation, often in a laboratory, collection, botanical garden, zoo, or aquarium. (Opposite: in-situ)
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: ex-situ

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: that part of the marine realm seaward of territorial waters within which nations have exclusive fishing rights.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: exclusive economic zone

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: travel undertaken to witness sites or regions of unique natural or ecologic quality, or the provision of services to facilitate such travel. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: ecotourism

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: chemical products of metabolism; the biological synthesis or breakdown carried out by cells or their components. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: metabolites

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: species whose occupancy area (plants) or home range (animals) are large enough and whose habitat requirements are wide enough that, if they are given a sufficiently large area for their protection, will bring other species under that protection. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: umbrella species

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the process by which plants, animals or microbes selected from the wild adapt to a special habitat created for them by humans.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: domestication

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: whole plants and plant parts (including seeds and fruits) used primarily in perfumery and pharmacy. Includes fresh, dried, uncut, cut, crushed, and powdered material. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: medicinal and aromatic plant material

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the use and development of animal genetic resources for the production of food and agriculture.  The use in production systems of AnGRs that already possess high levels of adaptive fitness to the environments concerned, and the deployment of sound genetic principles, will facilitate sustainable development of the AnGRs and the sustainable intensification of the production systems themselves. The wise use of AnGRs is possible without depleting domestic animal diversity. Development of AnGRs includes a broad mix of ongoing activities that must be well planned and executed for success, and compounded over time, hence with high value. It requires careful definition of breeding objectives, and the planning, establishment and maintenance of effective and efficient animal recording and breeding strategies. [FAO]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: utilization of farm animal genetic resources
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.objecttrans_en: utilization of farm animal genetic resources
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.objectname_en: utilization of farm animal genetic resources

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: safety aspects related to the application of biotechnologies and to the release into the environment of transgenic plants and other organisms particularly microorganisms that could negatively affect plant genetic resources, plant, animal or human health, or the environment. [BSWG/2/5: FAO Draft International Code of Conduct for Plant Biotechnology as it Affects the Conservation and Utilization of Plant Genetic Resources]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: biosafety

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: regions of ocean space encompassing coastal areas from river basins to estuaries to the seaward boundary of continental shelves and seaward margins of coastal current systems. They are relatively large regions, characterized by distinct bathymetry, hydrography, productivity and trophically linked populations. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: marine ecosystems

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: system of record by which the vigor of a nation's economy is measured. (Results are often listed as Gross National Product, or Gross Domestic Product.)
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: national income accounts

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the value of biodiversity in maintaining ecosystem functions over a range of environmental conditions. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: insurance value

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: swimming organisms that are able to move independently of water currents (opp. plankton). These include most fish, mammals, turtles, sea snakes, and aquatic birds.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: nekton

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - judicious use and management of nature and natural resources for the benefit of human society and for ethical reasons. [GBA] - artificial control of ecological relationships in an environment in order to maintain a particular balance among the species present. - the management of human use of the biosphere so that many yield the greatest sustainable benefit to current generations while maintaining its potential to meet the needs and aspirations of future generations: Thus conservation in positive, embracing preservations, maintenance, sustainable utilization, restoration, and enhancement of the natural environment. [WRI et al.]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: conservation

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: popular, charismatic species that serve as symbols and rallying points to stimulate conservation awareness and action.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: flagship species

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: characteristics of animals, such as the quantity or quality of the milk, meat, fiber, eggs, draught, etc. they (or their progeny) produce, which contribute directly to the value of the animals for the farmer, and that are identifiable or measurable at the individual level. Production traits of farm animals are generally quantitatively inherited, i.e. they are influenced by many genes whose expression in a particular animal also reflects environmental influences. [FAO]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: production traits

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - nutrient enrichment, typically in the form of nitrates and phosphates, often from human sources such as agriculture, sewage, and urban runoff. - process by which a lake, a river, part of a sea, etc. is enriched with nitrates, phosphates and other nutrients which favour the growth of algae and often kill other organisms by lack of oxygen. [JVG]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: eutrophication

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the propagation or preservation of animals outside their natural habitat (see ex-situ conservation), involving control by humans of the animals chosen to constitute a population and of mating choices within that population. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: captive breeding

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the various tests conducted in whole animals and other test systems, such as cell cultures, to determine the relative toxicity of a compound to living systems. These are referred to as pre-clinical studies - tests conducted and evaluated prior to the first administration of the compound to humans. Also included in this category are two-year carcinogenicity assays which typically overlap with the chemical testing phase. Pre-clinical tests include: toxicity (how poisonous it is and what side effects might be expected); bioavailability (how effectively it is taken up into the body and delivered to the tissue where it is needed); pharmacokinetics (how it is metabolised, and therefore how long it stays in the body); and whether it has the desired physiological effect. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: pre-clinical studies

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: marine benthic and pelagic ecosystems having substantial influence from the land.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: coastal waters

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: incorporation of genes of one species into a gene pool of another species.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: introgression

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: an organism which lives at the expense of another organism and which may help to limit the population of its host. This includes parasitoids, parasites, predators and pathogens [FAO bis].
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: natural enemy

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - any DNA molecule formed by joining DNA segments from different sources. - a strand of DNA synthesised in the laboratory by splicing together selected parts of DNA strands from different organic species, or by adding a selected part to an existing DNA strand. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: recombinant DNA (r-DNA)

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a measure of the genetic similarity between any pair of populations. Such distance may be based on phenotypic traits, allele frequencies or DNA sequences. For example, genetic distance between two populations having the same allele frequencies at a particular locus, and based solely on that locus, is zero. The distance for one locus is maximum when the two populations are fixed for different alleles. When allele frequencies are estimated for many loci, the genetic distance is obtained by averaging over these loci. [FAO]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: genetic distance

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: sometimes created by a COP to facilitate the process of negotiating text. When the Committee finishes its work it turns the text over to the COP which finalises and then formally adopts it during a plenary session.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: Committee of the Whole

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: random gene frequency changes in a small population due to chance alone.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: genetic drift

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the entire genetic constitution of an organism, or the genetic composition at a specific gene locus or set of loci.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: genotype

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the value of ecosystem functions.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: secondary value

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: entitlements assured by custom, law or property.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: rights

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - the conservation of components of biological diversity outside their natural habitats. [CBD] - keeping components of biodiversity alive away from their original habitat or natural environment. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: ex-situ conservation

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a breeding technique, most commonly used in domestic animals and sometimes in captive breeding of wild animals, in which semen is introduced into the female reproductive tract by artificial means. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: artificial insemination

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: selection leading to a consistent directional change in any character of a population through time, for example selection for larger eggs. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: directional selection

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: The Convention defines one permanent committee: the Subsidiary Body on Scientific, Technical and Technological Advice (SBSTTA). The Conference of the Parties may establish additional subsidiary bodies as needed; for example in 1996 it set up the Open-ended Ad Hoc Working Group on Biosafety..
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: Subsidiary Body of the Convention on Biological Diversity
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.objecttrans_en: Subsidiary Body of the Convention on Biological Diversity
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.objectname_en: subsidiary body of the convention on biological diversity

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the use of biological agents to reclaim soils and waters polluted by substances hazardous to human health and/or the environment; it is an extension of biological treatment processes that have been used traditionally to treat wastes in which micro-organisms typically are used to biodegrade environmental pollutants. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: bioremedation

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the Jakarta Mandate on Marine and Coastal Biological Diversity is a global consensus on the importance of marine and coastal biological diversity and is a part of the Ministerial Statement on the implementation of the Convention on Biological Diversity, as adopted by the Conference of the Parties at its second meeting held in Jakarta, Indonesia, 6-17 November 1995.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: Jakarta Mandate

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a small organic structure or cell from which a new organism may develop. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: germ cell

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the eggs of certain aquatic organisms or the act of producing such eggs or egg masses.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: spawn

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a technique that measures a biological response; the determination of the activity or concentration of a chemical. (See bioassay.)  [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: assay

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: this describes the outputs that may be obtained from combining different quantities of inputs. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: production function

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the microbially mediated process of chemical breakdown of a substance to smaller products caused by micro-organisms or their enzymes. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: biodegradation

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: under the Climate Change Convention (UNFCCC), adopted at COP-3 on 11 December 1997). The Kyoto Protocol commits Annex I Parties to individual, legally binding targets to limit or reduce their greenhouse gas emissions, adding up a total cut of at least 5% from 1990 levels in the period 2008-2012. The Protocol also establishes three innovative 'mechanisms', known as joint implementation, emissions trading and the clean development mechanism, which are designed to help Annex I Parties reduce the costs of meeting their emissions targets. The Kyoto Protocol was open for signature between 16 March 1998 and 15 March 1999. During that period, 84 countries signed the Protocol, including all but two Annex I Parties. In order to enter into force, the Protocol must be ratified (or adopted, approved, or acceded to) by 50 Parties to the Convention. As of July 2001, only five countries have ratified the Protocol, one being an Annex I Party.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: Kyoto Protocol

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: natural forest growth after some major disturbance (e.g. logging, serious fire, or insect attack). (Opp.: primary forest.)
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: secondary forest

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the close relationship of two organisms in proximity, with one benefiting and the other either benefiting (mutualism), not being significantly affected (commensalism), or being harmed (parasitism).
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: symbiosis

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the transformation of chemical or solar energy to biomass. Most primary production occurs through photosynthesis, whereby green plants convert solar energy, carbon dioxide, and water to glucose and eventually to plant tissue. In addition, some bacteria in the deep sea can convert chemical energy to biomass through chemosynthesis. [UNEP]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: primary productivity

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the conversion of a compound from one form to another by the actions of organisms or enzymes; synonym: bioconversion. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: biotransformation

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a designed artificial reef used to restore ailing coral reefs and to create new fishing and scuba diving sites. More info: What's a Reef Ball?
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: reef ball

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: see: non-consumptive value.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: passive use value

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: switching of a segment of a chromosome to another chromosome.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: translocation

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: organism containing two or more sets of genes or chromosomes.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: polyploid

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - the place or type of site where an organism or population naturally occurs. [CBD] - the space in which an organism, population, or species lives.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: habitat

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a dispersal stage of a plant or animal, such as fertilized eggs, larvae, or seeds.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: propagule

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: see: domesticated species.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: cultivated species

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: plants or plant parts valued for medicinal, savoury, cosmetic, flavouring, or aromatic qualities. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: herbs

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: see: indigenous peoples.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: native peoples

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a government agency or agencies responsible for regulating biotechnology, biosafety, intellectual property rights and other relevant aspects. [BSWG/2/5: FAO Draft International Code of Conduct for Plant Biotechnology as it Affects the Conservation and Utilization of Plant Genetic Resources]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: competent authority

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: this occurs when market prices are not equal to the social opportunity cost of resources. External effects or externalities are evidence of market failure. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: market failure

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a gene with a clear, unambiguous phenotype used in genetic analysis to identify individuals that carry it or other linked genes. May act as a probe to mark a nucleus, chromosome or locus. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: genetic marker

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the release of overwhelming numbers of a mass-produced biological control agent in the expectation of achieving a rapid reduction of a pest population without necessarily achieving continuing impact. [FAO bis]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: inundative release

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: see: alien species.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: introduced species

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the value to society of conserving environmental resources.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: conservation values

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: fixed or attached; unable to move.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: sessile

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - interspecific relationship in which both organisms benefit. Example: flower pollination by insects. - a kind of symbiotic relationship, such as the one between sea-anemones and clown-fishes, or corals and zooxanthellae, in which both species benefit; the relationship can be obligate or facultative for one or both
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: mutualism

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - pertaining to food or nutrition. - referring to the nutrients available to and used within a population, community, or ecosystem.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: trophic

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the preservation of seeds, semen, embryos, or micro-organisms at extremely low temperatures, below -130 °C; at these temperatures, water is absent, molecular kinetic energy is low, diffusion is virtually nil, and storage potential is expected to be extremely long. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: cryogenic storage

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: comprises (1999) Australia, Austria, Belgium, Canada, Czech Republic, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Japan, Republic of Korea, Luxembourg, Mexico, The Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Portugal, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey, the UK and the USA. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD)
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.objecttrans_en: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD)
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.objectname_en: organisation for economic co-operation and development (oecd)

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: recombinant protein drugs, recombinant vaccines and monoclonal antibodies (for therapeutic roles). Biopharmaceuticals are still only a small part of the pharmaceutical industry, but of increasing importance. (See biologics.) [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: biopharmaceutical

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the opportunities forgone by society, including externalities, in using a resource in some way. For biological resources this may be different than the market price of that resource. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: social opportunity cost

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the right to exclusively occupy and use a specified area of land. Tenure may also be limited to certain resources ("resource tenure") such as timber but not to all resources in a given area. Tenure may be held by individuals, communities, government, or corporations. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: land tenure

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: in molecular biology, a method developed to inject DNA into cells by mixing the DNA with small metal particles and then firing the particles into the host cell at very high speeds. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: biolistics

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: varied community of organisms living in the same small area, e.g. in the bark of a tree, on a wall, in a pond. [JVG]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: biocoenosis

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the return of an ecosystem to its original community structure, natural complement of species, and natural functions.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: ecosystem restoration

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: flow of money, goods or services deriving from the productive use of assets.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: income

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: advanced informed agreement refers to the principle that international exchange of transgenic plants and microorganisms that could adversely affect plants should not proceed without the informed agreement of, or contrary to the decision of, the competent authority in the recipient country. (See also prior informed consent.) [BSWG/2/5: FAO Draft International Code of Conduct for Plant Biotechnology as it Affects the Conservation and Utilization of Plant Genetic Resources]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: advanced informed agreement

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: conditions where genetic resources exist within ecosystems and natural habitats, and, in the case of domesticated or cultivated species, in the surroundings where they have developed their distinctive properties. [CBD]  - the conservation of ecosystems and natural habitats and the maintenance and recovery of viable populations of species in their natural surroundings and, in the case of domesticated or cultivated species, in the surroundings where they have developed their distinctive properties. [CBD] - the conservation of biodiversity within the evolutionary dynamic ecosystems of the original habitat or natural environment. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: in-situ conditions

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a culture of plant cells derived from pollen in a synthetic medium: the progeny generated will have a single set of chromosomes. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: pollen culture

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the change in the value of a resource that is due to an incremental change in its quantity. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: marginal values

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: includes genetic resources, organisms or parts thereof, populations, or any other biotic component of ecosystems with direct, indirect or potential use or value for humanity. (Syn.: biotic resources) [CBD]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: biological resources

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: see: non-consumptive value.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: non-use value

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: measurement of the characteristics that are important for production and adaptation, either of individual animals or of populations, most commonly in the context of comparative evaluation of the traits of animals or of populations. [FAO]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: evaluation

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the edges of continental landmasses, now covered with seawater; generally the most productive parts of the ocean.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: continental shelf

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the naming and assignment of organisms to taxa.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: taxonomy

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the knowledge, innovations and practices of local and indigenous communities. As used in the CBD, those elements of traditional knowledge that are relevant to the conservation and sustainable use of biodiversity. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: traditional knowledge

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the smallest isolated population having a good chance of surviving for a given number of years despite the foreseeable effects of demographic, environmental, and genetic events and natural catastrophes. (The probability of persistence and the time of persistence are often taken to be 99 percent and 1000 years, respectively.) [GBA]
