biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: minimum viable population

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the use of components of biological diversity in a way and at a rate that does not lead to the long-term decline of biological diversity, thereby maintaining its potential to meet the needs and aspirations of present and future generations. [CBD]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: sustainable use

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: set of species from a common ancestral species.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: clade

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: these are externalities where all parties using some resource impose external costs on all others.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: reciprocal externality

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: in plant breeding this refers to the process of undertaking a cross where one parent is from outside the immediate genepool of the other, i.e. landrace or primitive line crossed with a modern cultivar. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: wide crossing

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - a legally established land or water area under either public or private ownership that is regulated and managed to achieve specific conservation objectives. [GBA] - a geographically defined area which is designated or regulated and managed to achieve specific conservation objectives. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: protected area

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - a group of organisms capable of interbreeding freely with each other but not with members of other species. (Note by JVG: this is a simplified definition; species concept is much more complex.) - a taxonomic rank below a genus, consisting of similar individuals capable of exchanging genes or interbreeding. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: species

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: species in which the evolutionary process has been influenced by humans to meet their needs (syn.: cultivated species). [CBD]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: domesticated species

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: region of reproduction among individuals of different species.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: hybrid zone

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the differential multiplication and extinction of species as a result of differences in certain traits possessed by the organisms belonging to the various species, and causing a spread of the favouring traits through the fauna or flora as a whole. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: species selection

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a government grant of temporary monopoly rights on innovative processes or products.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: patent

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - the observed traits of an organism, resulting from an interaction of its genotype and its environment. - the characteristics of an organism that result from the interaction of its genetic constitution with the environment. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: phenotype

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the second and last period of the Cenozoic era extending from 2.5 million years ago to the present.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: Quaternary period

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: public goods to which it is impossible, or excessively costly, to operate any mechanism.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: non-exclusive goods

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a reduction in fitness and vigour of individuals as a result of increased homozygosity through inbreeding in a normally outbreeding population.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: inbreeding depression

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: an antimicrobial compound produced by living micro-organisms, used therapeutically or sometimes prophylactically in the control of infectious diseases. Over 4,000 antibiotics have been isolated, but only about 50 have achieved wide use. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: antibiotic

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: see: stabilizing selection.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: normalizing selection

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the establishment of a preparatory committee is a very important administrative step in the process of an international conference because it refines conference issues in seeking consensus. When world leaders meet at the conference itself, their only task is to approve pre-negotiated documents.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: preparatory committee (PrepCom)

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - a volatile hormone or behaviour-modifying agent. Normally used to describe sex attractants -for example bombesin for the moth Bombyx- but includes volatile aggression-stimulating agents (e.g. isoamyl acetate in honey bees). [CUB] - a hormone-like substance secreted into the environment by certain animals, especially insects. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: pheromone

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - a sequence of reactions undergone in a living organism. [CUB] - any means that allows the entry or spread of a pest. [FAO bis]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: pathway

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: bacteria that are the smallest photosynthetic cells (less than one micrometers; see picoplankton) in the open ocean; nearly ubiquitous in the sea.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: prochlorophyte

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: in the original location. (Opposite: ex-situ)
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: in-situ

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: all of the animals found in a given area.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: fauna

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: life cycle of a single organism; biological development of the individual.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: ontogeny

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a good which, once provided to one user, must be provided in the same amount to all users due to its non-rival and non-excludable nature. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: public good

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: commodities which are produced in such a way that a change in the output of one of them necessarily involves a change in the output of the other. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: joint products

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: adopted at  COP-1  (1995), the Berlin Mandate launched the talks that led to the adoption of the  Kyoto Protocol  (1997).
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: Berlin Mandate (under the climate change convention, UNFCCC)
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.objecttrans_en: Berlin Mandate (under the climate change convention, UNFCCC)
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.objectname_en: berlin mandate (under the climate change convention, unfccc)

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the change in income necessary to restore the consumer to its original level of utility after a price change. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: compensating variation

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the Alliance of Small Island States is a coalition of 42 (as of May 2000) low-lying and small island countries, most of which are members of the G-77, that are particularly vulnerable to sea-level rise. The AOSIS countries are united by the threat that climate change poses to their survival, and frequently adopt a common stance in negotiations.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: Alliance of Small Island States (AOSIS)

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the manipulation of inputs to, and outputs from, livestock production systems aimed at increasing production and / or productivity and / or changing product quality, while maintaining the long-term integrity of the systems and their surrounding environment, so as to meet the needs of both present and future human generations. Sustainable agricultural intensification respects the needs and aspirations of local and indigenous people, takes into account the roles and values of their locally adapted genetic resources, and considers the need to achieve long-term environmental sustainability within and beyond the agro-ecosystem. [FAO]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: sustainable intensification of animal production systems
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.objecttrans_en: sustainable intensification of animal production systems
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.objectname_en: sustainable intensification of animal production systems

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: contain the whole spectrum of ingredients present in the original herb, plus any new active compounds formed during processing. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: total extracts

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the collection of the data on phenotypic traits, marker allele frequencies or DNA sequences for two or more populations, and estimation of the genetic distances between each pair of populations. From these distances, the best representation of the relationships among all the populations may be obtained. [FAO]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: genetic distancing

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: application of phytosanitary [or other] measures in and around an infested area to prevent spread of a pest or a disease [FAO bis]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: containment

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a protozoan, characterised by having two lash-like structures (flagella) used for locomotion, often abundant in the open ocean. Many produce light and are one of the primary contributors to bioluminescence (green or red) in the ocean. Some dinoflagellates, known as zooxanthellae, are symbiotic in the tissues of corals and some other tropical invertebrates
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: dinoflagellate

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the head of state or government, the minister of foreign affairs, or another designated official indicates his or her country's agreement with the adopted text of the Convention or the Protocol and its intention to become a Party by signing.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: signature

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the period during which land is left to recover its productivity (reduced by cropping) mainly through accumulation of water, nutrients, attrition of pathogens, or a combination of all three. During this period, the land may be bare or covered by natural or planted vegetation. The term may be applied to the land itself or to the crop growing on it. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: fallow

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: copies of well-known drugs for which patent protection has expired. Companies specialising in generics invest little on research, or only on research in manufacturing procedures. The average price of a generic is 30 per cent below that for patented products. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: generics

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the number and variety of species found in a given area in a region.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: species diversity

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: see: domestic biodiversity.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: agricultural biodiversity

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - genetic material, especially its specific molecular and chemical constitution, that comprises the physical basis of the inherited qualities of an organism. - the genetic material which forms the physical basis ofheredity and which is transmitted from one generation to the next by means of germ cells. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: germplasm

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: rights arising from the past, present and future contributions of farmers in conserving, improving and making available plant or animal genetic resources, particularly those in centres of origin. [JVG]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: farmers rights

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the value of the best alternative use of a resource. This consists of the maximum value of other outputs we could and would have produced had we not used the resource to produce the item in question. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: opportunity cost

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the genetic variation existing among the species, breeds, cultivars and individuals of animal, plant and microbial species that have been domesticated, often including their immediate wild relatives. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: domestic biodiversity

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the rules that govern the proceedings of the COP, including the procedures for decision-making and participation.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: rules of procedure

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a micro-organism whose optimum growth is under extreme conditions of temperature, etc. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: extremophile

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a state that has not ratified the Convention and may attend meetings as an observer.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: non-party

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the discounted value of the net benefits of use of a resource.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: net present value

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: delegates who are called upon by the Chair (who takes into account the need for a political balance among various interests) to assist in carrying out specific tasks.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: friends of the chair

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - an organism that consumes part of the tissues of its host, usually without killing the host. - an organism which lives on or in another organism, feeding upon it. [FAO bis]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: parasite

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: evolution in two or more interacting species in which the evolutionary changes of each species influence the evolution of the other species.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: co-evolution

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the smallest known type of organism. A non cellular entity that consists minimally of protein and nucleic acid, and that can replicate only after entry into specific types of living cells, and then only by usurping the cell's own systems. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: virus

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - position in the food chain, determined by the number of energy-transfer steps to that level. - feeding level in food chain or pyramid; for example, herbivores (organisms that eat plants) constitute one trophic level.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: trophic level

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the term TRR encompasses intellectual property rights, but denotes broader 'bundles of rights' including for example, human rights, land rights, religious rights, and cultural property.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: traditional resource rights

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a major portion of the living environment of a particular region (such as a coniferous forest or grassland), characterized by its distinctive vegetation and maintained by local climatic conditions. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: biome

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: all measures to maintain live animal breeding populations, including those involved in active breeding programmes in the agro-ecosystem where they either developed or are now normally found, together with husbandry activities that are undertaken to ensure the continued contribution of these resources to sustainable food and agricultural production, now and in the future. [FAO]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: in situ conservation of farm animal genetic diversity
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.objecttrans_en: in situ conservation of farm animal genetic diversity
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.objectname_en: in situ conservation of farm animal genetic diversity

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the number of species within a region. (A term commonly used as a measure of species diversity, but technically only one aspect of diversity.)
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: species richness

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: that component of biodiversity that contributes to food and agriculture production. The term agrobiodiversity encompasses within-species, species and ecosystem diversity. [FAO]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: agrobiodiversity or agricultural biological diversity

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: in biogeography, having an extremely broad or global distribution.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: cosmopolitan

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: government or industry set standards for the production of safe, efficacious, and high-quality ingredients and products. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: Good Manufacturing Practices (GMP)

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the opportunity set for future generations can only be assured if the level of biodiversity they inherit is no less than that available to present generations. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: strong sustainable development principle

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: reproduction of a plant or animal without fusion of male and female gametes. It includes vegetative propagation, cell and tissue culture. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: asexual reproduction

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: referring to the top 200 meters of the ocean, seas and lakes.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: epipelagic

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: members of a group of diverse single-celled organisms; organisms lacking a nucleus. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: bacteria

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the degree of availability to biodegradation of pollutants in contaminated soil or land. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: bioavailability

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: official confinement of regulated articles for observation and research or for further inspection, testing or treatment. [FAO bis]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: quarantine

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a group of species found in the same place that share the same food resource. Example: the lizard species of a sand dune that feed on insects. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: guild

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the study of genomes including genome mapping, gene sequencing and gene function. The use of this information in the development of therapeutics. [CUB].
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: genomics

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a disease-causing micro-organism; a bacterium, fungus or virus.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: pathogen

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: native to and restricted to a specific geographic area.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: endemic

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - having enough information to be able to judge the safety or risks of an LMO. It can be used to indicate ways of handling risks. It is not synonymous with safety. Relatively low degree of familiarity may be compensated for by appropriate management practices. Familiarity can be increased as a result of a trial or experiment. This increased familiarity can then form a basis for future risk assessment. [BSWG/2/5: Panel of Experts on Biosafety, Cairo 1995] - knowledge and experience with an organism, the intended application and the potential receiving environment. [BSWG/2/5: UNEP International Technical Guidelines for Safety in Biotechnology] - familiarity comes from the knowledge and experience available for conducting a risk/safety analysis prior to scale-up of any new plant line or crop cultivar in a particular environment. Familiarity takes into account of but need not be restricted to knowledge and experience with: the crop plant, including its flowering/reproductive characteristics, ecological requirements, and past breeding experiences; the agricultural and surrounding environment of the trial site; specific trait(s) transferred to plant line(s); results from previous basic research including greenhouse/glasshouse and small-scale field research with the new plant line or with other plant lines having the same trait; the scale-up of lines of the crop plant developed by more traditional techniques of plant breeding; the scale-up of other plant lines developed by the same technique; the presence of related (and sexually compatible) plants in the surrounding natural environment, and knowledge of the potential for gene transfer between the crop
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: familiarity

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - an animal that kills and eats animals. - a natural enemy that preys and feeds on other animal organisms, mor than one of which are killed during its lifetime [FAO bis]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: predator

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: an index of well-being.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: welfare

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the maximum number of people, or individuals of species, that a particular environment can sustain without environmental damage. [JVG]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: carrying capacity

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a restriction (taboo, prohibition, harvesting season) which limits the use of resources to levels that are thought to be safe, e.g. conservation of a sufficient area of habitat to ensure the continued provision of ecological functions and services, at the ecosystem level. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: safe minimum standard

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a comprehensive analysis of the many environmental and demographic factors that affect survival of a population, usually small.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: population viability analysis

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a breed where the total number of breeding females and males is greater than 1,000 and 20 respectively; or the population size approaches 1,000 and the percentage of pure-bred females is close to 100 percent, and the overall population size is increasing. [FAO]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: breed not at risk

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the site on a chromosome occupied by a specific gene.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: locus

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a cell culture developed from a small portion of the meristem tissue of a plant. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: meristem tip culture

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: all of the plants found in a given area.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: flora

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: separation of one population into two or more reproductively isolated, independent evolutionary units.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: speciation

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the erosion of material such as coral rock and shells, that results from the direct action of living organisms such as boring sponges, fungi, worms, molluscs, or sea urchins.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: bioerosion

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: genetic changes that occur within an evolutionary line.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: phyletic evolution

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: in taxonomy and systematics, the highest level of classification below the kingdom. For instance, Mollusca (slugs, snails, clams, squids, etc.) constitute a phylum. [JVG]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: phylum

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: economic values derived from direct use or interaction with a biological resource or resource system. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: direct use value

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: based on the tradition of the UN, Parties are organised into five regional groups. These groups are: Africa, Asia, Eastern Europe, Latin America and the Caribbean (GRULAC) and the Western Europe and Others Group (WEOG). The others in WEOG include Australia, Canada, Iceland, New Zealand, Norway, Switzerland and the US, but not Japan, which is in the Asian Group. The regional groups meet privately to discuss issues and nominate bureau members and other officials.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: regional group

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the transfer of pollen from the stamen of a flower to the stigma of a flower of different genotype, but usually of the same species. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: cross-pollination

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a technique of fusing two cells from different species to create one hybrid cell for the purpose of combining some of the genetic characteristics of each original. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: cell fusion

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - control of pests by using predators to eat them. - pest control strategy making use of living natural enemies, antagonists or competitors and other self-replicating biotic entities. [FAO bis]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: biological control

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the study of birth rates, death rates, age distributions, and size of populations. It is a fundamental discipline within the larger field of population biology and ecology.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: demography

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: values obtained through the use of a resource. This includes direct and indirect use values and instrumental values. Preservation in this sense is as much a use as development. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: use value

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a breed where it is no longer possible to recreate the breed population. Extinction is absolute when there are no breeding males (semen), breeding females (oocytes), nor embryos remaining. [FAO]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: extinct breed

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a category of in-session documents containing new proposals or outcomes of in-session work for use only during the session.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: Conference Room Papers (CRPs)

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the COP or the Committee of the Whole may establish an open-ended meeting wherein Parties can negotiate before forwarding agreed text to the plenary for formal adoption. Observers can generally attend.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: contact group

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the value to society of converting environmental resources to development uses. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: development values

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the tip of a growing plant shoot or root. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: meristem

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - groups of microscopic organisms, some of which cannot be detected without the aid of a light or electron microscope, including the viruses, the prokaryotes (bacteria and archaea), and eukaryotic life forms, such as protozoa, filamentous fungi, yeasts and micro-algae. [CUB] - a micro-organism is a protozoean, fungus, bacterium, virus or other microscopic self-replicating biotic entity. [FAO bis]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: micro-organisms

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: biological assimilation of atmospheric nitrogen to form organic nitrogen-containing compounds.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: nitrogen fixation

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - cell or organism that contains one set of chromosomes. - having the number of chromosomes present in the normal germ cell equal to half the number in the normal somatic cell. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: haploid

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: loss of genetic diversity between and within populations of the same species over time; or reduction of the genetic basis of a species due to human intervention, environmental changes, etc.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: genetic erosion

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: as defined by the Convention on Biological Diversity, its role is to provide under the guidance of the COP financial resources to help developing countries implement the Convention; the GEF is operating the mechanism on an interim basis.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: financial mechanism

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - the use of scientific data to identify and characterize the nature and magnitude of hazards, if any, and the likelihood of hazards being realized. [BSWG/2/5: Report of Panel of Experts on Biosafety] - the measure to estimate what harm might be caused, how likely it would be to occur and the scale of the estimated damage. [BSWG/2/5: UNEP International Technical Guidelines for Safety in Biotechnology]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: risk assessment

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: all of the organisms, including animals, plants, fungi, and microorganisms, found in a given area.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: biota

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the value of the system characteristics upon which all ecosystem functions depend.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: primary value

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: it is a function of primary value and total economic value. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: total environmental value

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the span of geological time preceding the Recent epochs, during which the human species evolved. It began 2.5 million years ago and ceased with the end of the last Ice Age 10.000 years ago.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: Pleistocene

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: arge-scale evolution, entailing major changes in biological traits.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: macroevolution

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a herbicide which acts after the seed has germinated.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: post-emergent

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: value, defined by willingness to pay, to ensure that peoples' offspring or future generations inherit a particular environmental asset. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: bequest value

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the SBSTTA delivers its advice to the COP in the form of recommendations that are numbered sequentially.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: recommendation of the SBSTTA

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: an introduced species which invades natural habitats.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: invasive species

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: after signing the Convention, a country must ratify it, for which it often needs the approval of the parliament or other legislature. For the CBD the instrument of ratification is submitted to the UN Secretary-General in New York, who acts as the Depositary. At the date of submission the country becomes a Party to the Convention; 90 days later the Convention enters into force for that country. As of 29 December 2000 the CBD has 180 parties. [JVG]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: ratification

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the process of excising segments of DNA from one species of organism and inserting them into the DNA of another species. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: recombinant DNA technology

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: as a regional economic integration organisation, the European Union can be and is a Party to the Convention. However it does not have a separate vote from its members. Under the CBD process, the 15 members (1995) of the European Union meet in private to agree on common positions for the negotiations. The country that holds the EU Presidency -a position that rotates every six months- then speaks for the group as a whole. Individual member states are allowed to make statements emphasising their specific points of view and priorities as long as they are not contradictory with the EU common position.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: European Union

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: processes that characterize habitat fragmentation and the concomitant creation of edges.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: edge effect

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: (1) not native to a given area; either intentionally transplanted from another region or introduced accidentally. (2) in plant breeding, it refers to plants types that are from outside a breeding region or exhibit traits that are uncommon to the prevalent crop plant type. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: exotic

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the COP is the supreme body of the Convention. It currently meets every two year to review and steer the Convention's progress. The word 'conference' is not used here in the sense of 'meeting' but rather of 'association', which explains the seemingly redundant expression 'fifth meeting of the Conference of the Parties'. Overview of COP meetings.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: Conference of the Parties (COP)

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a phenomenon occurring when corals under stress expel their mutualistic microscopic algae, called zooxanthellae. This results in a severe decrease or even total loss of photosynthetic pigments. Since most reef building corals have white calcium carbonate skeletons, the latter show through the corals' tissue, and the coral reef appears bleached. [JVG]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: coral bleaching

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: storage of DNA, which may or may not be the complete genome, but should always be accompanied by inventory information. (Note: at the present time, animals cannot be reestablished from DNA alone.) [FAO]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: DNA bank

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: forest area for which use rights are granted by governments to residents whose livelihoods customarily depend on extracting forest products from the specified area.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: extractive reserve

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - a dynamic complex of plant, animal, fungal, and micro-organism communities and their associated non-living environment interacting as a functional unit; the organisms living in a given environment, such as a tropical forest, a coral reef or a lake, and the physical part of the environment that impinges on them. [GBA modified by JVG] - a complex of organisms and their environment, interacting as a defined ecological unit (natural or modified by human activity, e.g. agroecosystem), irrespective of political boundaries. [FAO bis] - a community of organisms in their physical environment.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: ecosystem

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: history or evolutionary development of any plant or animal species.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: phylogeny

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: an organism whose DNA is enclosed in nuclear membranes. The vast majority of species (plants, animals, protista,...) are eukaryotic. (Opp.: prokaryote.) [JVG]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: eukaryote

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: those animal species that are used, or may be used, for the production of food and agriculture, and the populations within each of them. These populations within each species can be classified as wild and feral populations, landraces and primary populations, standardized breeds, selected lines, and any conserved genetic material. [FAO]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: farm animal genetic resources (AnGR)

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - the variability among living organisms from all sources including, inter alia, terrestrial, marine and other aquatic ecosystems and the ecological complexes of which they are part; this includes diversity within species, between species and of ecosystems. [CBD] (Syn.: biodiversity) It appears that the term 'biological diversity' was first defined as including two related concepts, genetic diversity (the amount of genetic variability within species) and ecological diversity (the number of species in a community of organisms) by Norse and McManus (1980). There are at least 25 more definitions of biological diversity. The one given on top is the definition used in the Convention text. Other definitions: - the totality of genes, species, and ecosystems in a region or the world. - the variety of life in all its forms, levels and combinations, encompassing genetic diversity, species diversity and ecosystem diversity. [FAO] - a variety or multiformity, the condition of being different in character or quality (R.Patrick,1983) - the variety and variability among living organisms and the ecological complexes in which they occur. Diversity can be defined as the number of different items and their relative frequency. For biological diversity, these items are organized at many levels, ranging from complete ecosystems to the chemical structures that are the molecular basis of heredity. Thus, the term encompasses different ecosystems, species, genes, and their relative abundance (OTA, 1987). - the variety of the world's organisms, including their genetic diversity and the assemblages they form. It is the blanket term for the natural biological wealth that undergirds human life and well-being. The breadth of the concept reflects the interrelatedness of genes, species and ecosystems (Reid & Miller, 1989). - the wealth of life on earth including the millions of plants, animals, and micro-organisms as well as the genetic information they contain and the ecosystems that they create (AID, 1989). - the variety of life and its processes (U.S. Forest Service, 1990). - encompasses all species of plants, animals, and microorganisms and the ecosystems and ecological processes of which they are parts. It is an umbrella term for the degree of nature's variety, including both the number and frequency of ecosystems, species, or genes in a given assemblage (McNeely et al., 1990). - the variety of life on all levels of organization, represented by the number and relative frequencies of items (genes, organisms and ecosystems (EPA, 1990). - the variety of genes, genotypes and genepools and their relationships with the environment at molecular, population, species and ecosystem levels (FAO, 1990). - the genetic, taxonomic and ecosystem variety in living organisms of a given area, environment, ecosystem or the whole planet (McAllister, 1991). - the full range of variety and variability within and among living organisms and the ecological complexes in which they occur; encompasses ecosystems or community diversity, species diversity and genetic diversity (Pending legislation, U.S. Congres 1991). - those environmental goals that go beyond human health concerns (Environmental Law Institute, Fischman, 1991). - the variety of life and its processes. It includes the variety of living organisms, the genetic differences among them, and the communities and ecosystems in which they occur (Keystone Dialogue, 1991) - the variety and variability of all animals, plants and micro-organisms on earth, - can be considered at three levels - genetic diversity (variability within species), species diversity, and habitat diversity (Overseas Development Administration, 1991). - I suggest a fourth category - functional diversity - the variety of different responses to environmental change, especially the diverse space and time scales with which organisms react to each other and the environment (J. Steele, 1991). - the totality of genes, species, and ecosystems in a region (WRI, IUCN and UNEP, 1992). - the total variety of life on earth. It includes all genes, species and ecosystems and the ecological processes of which they are part (ICBP, 1992). - full range of variety and variability within and among living organisms, their associations, and habitat-oriented ecological complexes. Term encompasses ecosystem, species, and landscape as well as intraspecific (genetic) levels of diversity (Fiedler & Jain, 1992). - the variety of organisms considered at all levels, from genetic variants belonging to the same species through arrays of species to arrays of genera, families, and still higher taxonomic levels; includes the variety of ecosystems, which comprise both the communities of organisms within particular habitats and the physical conditions under which they live (Wilson, 1992). - complex beyond understanding and valuable beyond measure, biodiversity is the total variety of life on Earth (Ryan, 1992). - the structural and functional variety of life forms at genetic, population, species, community, and ecosystems levels (Sandlund et al., 1993). - is the ensemble and the interactions of the genetic, the species and the ecological diversity, in a given place and at a given time (di Castri, 1995). - is the ensemble and the hierarchical interactions of the genetic, taxonomic and ecological scales of organization, at different levels of integration (di Castri & Younès, 1996). - the use of living organisms to control pests or disease. May be a single organism or a combination of a number of different ones. [CUB] - a natural enemy, antagonist or competitor, and other self-replicating biotic entity used for pest control. [FAO bis]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: biological diversity

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: any process that uses complete living cells or their components (e.g. enzymes, chloroplasts) to effect desired physical or chemical changes. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: bioprocess

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a state (or regional economic integration organization such as the EU) that ratifies, accepts or approves the CBD or accedes thereto becomes a Contracting Party. Each Party to the Convention is represented at sessions of the Convention bodies by a national delegation consisting of one or more officials who are empowered to represent, and negociate on behalf of, their government. Based on the tradition of the UN, Parties are organised into five regional groups, mainly for the purposes of electing the Bureaus.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: Party

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: isolating the active compound out of a natural product mixture. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: deconvolution

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a pest of potential economic importance to the area endangered thereby and not yet present there, or present but not widely distributed and being offically controlled. [FAO bis]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: quarantine pest

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: synonymous with micro-organism.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: microbe

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: statements of ethical principle that inform the private and social valuation of biological resources. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: ethical values

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: in plants, a line produced by repeated selfing and selection. Results in truebreeding and a fixed genotype. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: in-bred line

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the value of the future information made available through the preservation of a resource. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: quasi-option value

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a natural enemy of insects which was isolated from dead silk worms. This bacterium kills insects with the help of a protein, the so-called Bt-toxin. More than 50 Bt-toxins have been detected, each with its own characteristics. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt)

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: see: tissue culture.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: in vitro culture

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the conversion of a compound from one form to another by the actions of organisms or enzymes; synonym: biotransformation. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: bioconversion

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: organisms that float on the sea surface.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: pleuston

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a specific population or group of populations.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: stock

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a regional group coalition of the non EU developed countries, which acts as an information sharing and discussion forum. JUSSCANNZ stands for Japan, the US, Switzerland, Canada, Australia, Norway and New Zealand. Iceland, Mexico, the Republic of Korea and other invited countries may also attend meetings.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: JUSSCANNZ

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - genetic material of plants, animals or micro-organisms, including modern cultivars and breeds, primitive varieties and breeds, landraces and wild/weedy relatives of crop plants or domesticated animals, of value as a resource for future generations of humanity. [GBA] - genetic material of actual or potential value. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: genetic resources

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a committee that assists the Conference of the Parties.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: subsidiary body

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: genetic variability among individuals within populations and variability among populations.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: heterozygosity

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: also known as genetic use restriction technology (GURT), refers to the use of an external chemical to switch on or off a plant's genetic traits.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: traitor technology

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the long chain of molecules in most cells that carries the genetic message and controls all cellular functions in most forms of life. [FAO]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid)

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a population of cells all descended from a single cell; also called a clone. A group of organisms within a species or variety distinguished by one or more minor characteristics; a variety of bacterium or fungus used for culturing. The term is mostly associated with cells, bacteria, fungi and viruses, but is sometimes applied to plants. [CUB].
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: strain

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: categories where critical or endangered breeds are being maintained by an active public conservation programme or within a commercial or research facility. [FAO]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: endangered-maintained breed

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: is the amount an individual is willing to pay to acquire some good or service. This may be elicited from stated or revealed preference approaches. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: willingness to pay

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a global initiative for the promotion of sustainable tourism, Berlin, 8 March 1997.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: Berlin Declaration (under the biodiversity convention, CBD)
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.objecttrans_en: Berlin Declaration (under the biodiversity convention, CBD)
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.objectname_en: berlin declaration (under the biodiversity convention, cbd)

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: any change in the genotype of an organism occurring at the gene, chromosome or genome level.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: mutation

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - the identification of genes coding for useful traits and their introduction into other species of plants and animals ('transgenic species'). Genetic engineering offers the possibility of correcting genetic defects at source, or introducing new, desirable genetic characteristics that will stay with the subject and may be passed on to its successors. - manipulation of DNA to form a hybrid molecule, a new combination of non-homologous DNA (so-called recombinant DNA). The technique allows the bypassing of all the biological constraints to genetic exchange and mixing and may even permit the combination of genes from widely differing species. Genetic engineering developed in the early 1970s. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: genetic engineering

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: is responsible for directing the work of the COP or of the SBSTTA. Its ten members are delegates elected by each of the five regional groups and they include, - for the COP: the COP President, eight Vice-Presidents, and a rapporteur; - for the SBSTTA: the SBSTTA Chair, eight Vice-Chairs, and a rapporteur.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: bureau

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: MOSAICC is a voluntary code of conduct developed to facilitate easy access to and international circulation of microbial genetic resources (MGRs) for the benefit of sciences and world-wide sustainable development in the framework of the Convention on Biological Diversity. [see BCCM]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: MOSAICC

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: gases, such as carbon dioxide and methane, that tend to trap heat radiating from the Earth's surface, thus causing warming in the lower atmosphere. The major GHGs causing climate change are carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>), methane (CH<sub>4</sub>), and nitrous oxide (N<sub>2</sub>O). The Kyoto Protocol also addresses hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), perfluorocarbons (PFCs), ans sulphur hexafluoride (SF<sub>6</sub>).
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: greenhouse gases  (GHGs)

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the intermittent (regular or irregular) surveillance to ascertain the extent of compliance with a predetermined standard or degree of deviation from an expected norm (Hellawell, 1991.) [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: monitoring

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a philosophy and healing system developed over thousands of years in India, in which patients are characterized by the elements of earth, water, fire, air, and ether. Employs botanical preparations, usually combinations of a number of herbs. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: Ayurveda

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - crossing of individuals from genetically different strains, populations or species. - the act of crossing two different individual organisms of differing genetic constitution from different populations or different species. [CUB] - a molecular procedure in which single strands of DNA and/or RNA are mixed and subsequently bind to one another. The degree of binding is a measure of the relatedness of the strands. The procedure is used to detect RNA or DNA using suitable probes. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: hybridization

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the breeding of distinct and genotypic types or forms in plants. This may entail the transfer of pollen from one individual to the stigma of another of different genotype. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: cross-breeding

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the cross of a hybrid with either of its parents (or a genetically equivalent individual). [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: backcross

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the use of molecular markers to follow the inheritance of genes, particularly those genes which cannot be readily identified. Selection of a marker flanking a gene of interest allows selection for the presence (or absence) of a gene in a new progeny. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: marker assisted selection

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: controlled and regulated harvesting of forest trees, combined with silvicultural and protective measures, to sustain and increase the commercial value of subsequent stands; relies on natural regeneration of native species. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: natural forest management system

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the annual migratory behavior of adult fish -such as salmon and lamprey- from the ocean into freshwater rivers and lakes in order to spawn.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: anadromous

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a conservation agency buys up some of a developing country's international debt ("secondary" debt) on the world's money market. The agency then promises to dispose of the debt in return for a promise from the indebted country that it will look after a conservation area. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: debt-for-nature swaps

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: field-trained biodiversity collection and inventory specialist recruited from local areas.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: parataxonomist

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a book listing, with descriptions and illustrations, all animals that live in a given area. [JVG]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: Fauna

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: any animal without backbone or spinal column.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: invertebrate

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: those Central and East European countries and former republics of the Soviet Union that are in transition to a market economy.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: countries with economies in transition

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a genetically determined characteristic that enhances the ability of an organism to cope with its environment.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: adaptation

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: species that are, often genetically impoverished, of low fecundity, dependent on patchy or unpredictable resources, extremely variable in population density, persecuted or otherwise prone to extinction in human-dominated landscapes. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: threatened species

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: any cell other than a germ cell.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: somatic cell

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: all activities associated with the description of AnGR aimed at better knowledge of these resources and their state. Characterization by a country of its AnGR will incorporate development of necessary descriptors for use, identification of the country's sovereign AnGR; baseline and advanced surveying of these populations including their enumeration and visual description, their comparative genetic description in one or more production environments, their valuation, and ongoing monitoring of those AnGR at risk. [FAO]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: characterization of animal genetic resources

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: protocols and any amendments to them are not binding in international law until they have been ratified by an agreed number of countries. In the case of the CBD, ratification by 30 countries was needed for the treaty to enter into force. The CBD entered into force for the first 30 Parties on 29 December 1993. It enters into force for other Parties 90 days after each ratifies. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: entry into force

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a scientific discipline that comprises all aspects of the gathering, storing, handling, analysing, interpreting and spreading of biological information. Involves powerful computers and innovative programmes which handle vast amounts of coding information on genes and proteins from genomics programmes. Comprises the development and application of computational algorithms for the purpose of analysis, interpretation, and prediction of data for the design of experiments in the biosciences. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: bioinformatics

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the synthesis of molecules by living organisms or their components. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: biosynthesis

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: on the instructions of the President or Chair, delegates may meet in private to discuss specific matters in order to consolidate different views, reach a compromise, and produce an agreed proposal, often in the form of written text.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: informal contact group

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a collective name for land-use systems and technologies where woody perennials (tree, shrubs, palms, bamboos, etc.) are deliberately used on the same land management unit as agricultural crops and/or animals, either in some form of spatial arrangement or temporal sequence. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: agroforestry

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a Party may accept a decision of the COP while noting its reservations and concerns for the record. However, no reservations may be made to the Convention itself or to the Protocol.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: reservation

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: plant or animal species that are taxonomically related to crop or livestock species and serve as potential sources for genes in breeding of new varieties of those crops or livestock.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: wild relative

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a cross between parents of similar genetic constitution which could be from the same blood line (shared ancestry). [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: in-bred

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a set of partially isolated populations belonging to the same species. The different populations are able to exchange individuals and recolonize sites in which the species has recently become extinct.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: metapopulation

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: see: biological resources
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: biotic resources

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: process by which the genotypes in a population that are best adapted to the environment increase in frequency relative to less well-adapted genotypes over a number of generations.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: natural selection

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a receptor- or enzyme-based screen against which a range of materials can be run, including natural products such as plants, marine organisms, fungi, and micro-organisms, but also synthetic compounds. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: mechanism-based screening

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: see: indigenous peoples.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: tribal peoples

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: entails the search for economically valuable genetic and biochemical resources from nature (ref.: K. ten Kate, 1995. Biopiracy or Green Petroleum? Expectations & Best Practice in Bioprospecting. - Overseas Development Administration, Environment Policy Department, London).
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: bioprospecting

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: rate at which females produce offspring.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: fecundity

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: pertaining to the evolutionary history of a particular group of organisms.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: phylogenetic

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - an ecologically based strategy that relies on natural mortality factors, such as natural enemies, weather, and crop management, and seeks to control tactics that disrupt these factors as little as possible while enhancing their effectiveness. [GBA] - the challenging or control of pests through a tailored programme of different strategies including biological control agents and agrochemicals. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: integrated pest management

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a databank that contains inventories of farm animal genetic resources and their immediate wild relatives, including any information that helps to characterize these resources. [FAO]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: animal genetic resources databank

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: an area with a high number of species, which might be recognized on a global, regional or local scale.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: center of diversity

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the science of cultivating forest crops (usually timber), based on a knowledge of forest tree characteristics.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: silviculture

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - the region near the border of a protected area. - a transition zone between areas managed for different objectives.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: buffer zone

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: collections of organisms that are maintained to provide permanent, physical documentation of species identifications and associated data resulting from inventories.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: voucher specimens

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: vaccines, therapeutic serums, toxoids, antitoxins and analogous biological products used to induce immunity to infectious diseases or harmful substances of biological origin. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: biologics

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the ocean shore, including the rocky intertidal, sandy beaches, and salt marshes.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: littoral

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: process by which the consequences of proposed projects or programs are evaluated as an integral part of planning the project, alternatives are analysed, and the general public has ample opportunity to comment.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: environmental impact assessment (EIA)

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: groupings or populations within a species that are distinguishable by morphological characteristics or, sometimes, by physiological or behavioural traits.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: subspecies

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: in-session documents that contain draft reports and texts for adoption by the COP or the subsidiary body, often in all six UN languages.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: L.docs

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: all input-output relationships, over time, at a particular location. The relationships will include biological, climatic, economic, social, cultural and political factors, which combine to determine the productive potential of a particular livestock enterprise. - high-input production environment: a production environment where all rate-limiting inputs to animal production can be managed to ensure high levels of survival, reproduction and output. Output and production risks are constrained primarily by managerial decisions. - medium-input production environment: a production environment where management of the available resources has the scope to overcome the negative effects of the environment on animal production, although it is common for one or more factors to limit output, survival or reproduction in a serious fashion. - low-input production environment: a production environment where one or more rate-limiting inputs impose continuous or variable severe pressure on livestock, resulting in low survival, reproductive rate or output. Output and production risks are exposed to major influences which may go beyond human management capacity. [FAO]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: production environment

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: evolution of characteristics of two or more species to their mutual advantage.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: co-adaptation

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the scientific study of the interactions of living organisms and their environment.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: ecology

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the absence of oxygen in water and sediments.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: anoxia

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: to ship, offer for shipment, offer for entry, import, receive for transportation, carry or otherwise transport or move, or allow to be moved into, through, or within the United States. (See also safe transfer.) [BSWG/2/5: US Federal Register, 7 Code of Federal Regulations part 340, Restrictions on the Introduction of Regulated Articles, 1993]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: move (moving, movement)

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: see in-bred.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: self-pollinated

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the cultivation of ornamental and vegetable plants in gardens or smallholdings (market gardens). Latin: hortus = garden. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: horticulture

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the first period of the Cenozoic era, beginning 65 million years ago and closing with the start of the Pleistocene, 2.5 million years ago.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: Tertiary period

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: planktonic organisms ranging in size from 0.2 to 2.0 micrometers.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: picoplankton

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: these are externalities in which the external costs or benefits of the resource use are "one way". [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: unidirectional externality

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: The governments of the world that recognise the Convention on Biological Diversity have affirmed the existence of a taxonomic impediment to sound management and conservation of biodiversity. Removal of this impediment is a crucial, rate-determining step in the proper implementation of the Convention's objectives. There is an urgent need to train and support more taxonomic experts, and to strengthen the infrastructure required to discover and understand the relationships among the world's biological diversity. The Darwin Declaration.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: Darwin Declaration (1998), The

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - a variety of a plant produced by selective breeding. - a cultivated variety (genetic strain) of a domesticated crop plant. - distinct form or variety of domesticated plant derived through breeding and selection and maintained through cultivation. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: cultivar

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - kind of insect whose larvae develop within and kill their host. - an insect parasitic only in its immature stages, killing its host in the process of its development, and free living as an adult. [FAO bis]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: parasitoid

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the country supplying genetic resources collected from in-situ sources, including populations of both wild and domesticated species, or taken from ex-situ sources, which may or may not have originated in that country. [CBD]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: country providing genetic resources

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - seed that does not survive drying and freezing. - seed that cannot withstand either drying or temperatures of less than 10° C and cannot therefore be stored for long periods as orthodox seeds can. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: recalcitrant seed

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a medicine of plant origin, in crude or processed form; used to represent herbal, or plant-based, medicines that are not consumed as isolated compounds (as are pharmaceuticals); includes single herb, herb combination, and herb combined with non-herbal ingredient products; delivery formats include capsules, tablets, herbal teas, extracts, tinctures, and bulk herbs. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: botanical medicine

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the sum total of technical, policy, and logistical operations involved in understanding (characterization), using and developing (utilization), maintaining (conservation), accessing, and sharing the benefits of animal genetic resources. [FAO]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: management of farm animal genetic resources
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.objecttrans_en: management of farm animal genetic resources
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.objectname_en: management of farm animal genetic resources

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: exchange of genetic traits between populations by movement of individuals, gametes or spores.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: gene flow

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a molecule with similar structure to DNA that is involved in a number of cell activities, especially protein synthesis. Some viruses have RNA as their genetic material. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: RNA

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a protein which catalyses the conversion of a substrate to a product. Other than a few well-established enzymes such as papein and trypsin, most enzyme names can be recognised by the suffix -ase, e.g. cellulase, protease, etc. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: enzyme

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: markets used in place of the missing markets for environmental resources. Surrogate markets are at least existing markets for resources with some of the properties of the non-marketed resource being valued. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: surrogate markets

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - the molecule that controls inheritance. - the molecule that generally encodes all genetic information. It consists of two strands or chains of sub-units, known as nucleotides. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA)

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: protected areas designated specifically to protect genetic variability of particular species. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: in-situ gene banks

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a taxonomic rank below subspecies in zoology and botany, varieties are often the result of selective breeding and diverge from the parent species or subspecies in distinct but relatively minor ways. Usage varies in different countries. [CUB, modified by JVG]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: variety

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - all organisms produced through the use of recombinant DNA technology, with a wider range of modifying technologies relevant when considering living modified prokaryotes and yeast. [BSWG/2/5: Report of the Panel of Experts on Biosafety, Cairo 1995] - genetically modified organisms (GMOs) whose genetic material does not occur naturally by mating or natural recombination. [BSWG/2/5: Report of UNEP Expert Panel IV]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: living modified organisms (LMOs)

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: set of species containing a common ancestor and all its descendants.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: monophyletic group

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: include enzymes, fine chemicals, speciality food products and food ingredients. Non-medical diagnostics for detection of pesticides in the environment and contaminants in food. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: speciality biotechnology products

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the generation of proteins (specifically enzymes) with subtly modified structures, thus conferring new properties such as changed catalytic specificity or thermal stability. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: protein engineering

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: an organisation constituted by sovereign States of a given region, to which its member States have transferred competence in respect of matters governed by this Convention and which has been duly authorised, in accordance with its internal procedures, to sign, ratify, accept, approve or accede to it. [CBD]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: regional economic integration organisation

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the G-77 was founded in 1964 in the context of the UN Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) and now functions throughout the UN system, comprising some 132 (in 1999) developing country members. Developing countries generally work through the Group of 77 and China to establish common negotiating positions on issues of interest to them, such as finance and technology transfer. However, because the G-77 and China is a diverse group with different interests, individual developing countries also intervene in debates, as do groups within the G-77, such as the African Group and AOSIS.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: Group of 77 and China

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: determination of the relative positions of genes on a DNA molecule (chromosome or plasmid) and of the distance, in linkage units or physical units, between them. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: gene mapping

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: productive forest where harvesting regulations are enforced, silvicultural treatments are carried out, and trees are protected from fires and diseases. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: managed forest

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: unlike decisions, resolutions do not generally become part of the formal body of decisions that guide the work of the COP. They are directives that guide, opinions rather than permanent legal acts.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: resolution

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: all organic matter that derives from the photosynthetic conversion of solar energy. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: biomass

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a contained vessel or other structure in which chemical reactions are carried out (usually on an industrial scale), mediated by a biological system, enzymes or cells. A bioreactor can range in size from a small container to an entire building. CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: bioreactor

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - all the organisms that live in a given habitat and affect one another as part of the food web or through their various influences on the physical environment. [GBA] - an integrated group of species inhabiting a given area; the organisms within a community influence one another's distribution, abundance and evolution. (A Human Community is a social group of any size whose members reside in a specific locality.) [WRI et al.]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: community

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: natural selection is the differential contribution of offspring to the next generation by various genetic types belonging to the same populations. Artificial selection is the intentional manipulation by man of the fitness of individuals in a population to produce a desired evolutionary response. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: selection
