biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - the use of living organisms to control pests or disease. May be a single organism or a combination of a number of different ones. [CUB] - a natural enemy, antagonist or competitor, and other self-replicating biotic entity used for pest control. [FAO bis]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: biological control agent

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - (= do-no-harm principle) a proactive method of dealing with the environment that places the burden of proof on those whose activities could harm the environment. (Opposite: wait-and-see principle) - if the costs of current activities are uncertain, but are potentially both high and irreversible, the precautionary principle holds that society should take action before the uncertainty is resolved. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: precautionary principle

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: breeding method whereby seed from a number of individuals is selected to form the next generation. Selection criteria are relaxed until later generations and crosses are performed at random. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: mass selection

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: procedure to establish the genotype of a parent by recording the genetic status of offspring/progeny. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: progeny testing

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a homozygous, pure breeding group of individuals phenotypically distinct from other members of the same species. Broader than strain. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: line

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the research on and development of agricultural products such as crop varieties and crop protection products by modifying genes to confer desirable properties such as pest resistance or improved nutritional profiles. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: agrobiotechnology

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - a species that has been transported by human activities, intentional or accidental, into a region where it does not naturally occur. (Also known as an exotic, introduced, nonindigenous, or nonnative species.) - a species occurring in an area outside of its historically known natural range as a result of intentional or accidental dispersal by human activities. (Also known as an exotic or introduced species.) [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: alien species

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a statistical measure of the dispersion of a set of values about its mean.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: variance

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a pesticide which is active towards a wide variety of weeds or other pests; often used to describe an antibiotic that is effective against a wide range of micro-organisms. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: broad spectrum

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: growing vegetation tends to absorb carbon dioxide (CO2) from the atmosphere. Calculating the effect of sinks (by land-use change and forestry) is methodologically complex and still needs to be clarified.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: sinks

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: group of genetically identical individuals.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: biotype

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: medicinal products based on standardised active ingredients within a herbal base. This term is sometimes used more broadly to include all plant-based medicines. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: phytomedicine

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: species so similar to each other as to be difficult to distinguish by human observers.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: sibling species

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the diversity among biological communities and their physical settings, characterised by differences in species composition, physical structure, and function. It is the highest level of biological diversity.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: ecosystem diversity

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: The Cartagena Protocol on Biosafety (CBD) - Text of the Cartagena Protocol.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: Cartagena Protocol, The

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: low in nutrients and in primary production.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: oligotrophic

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a molecular selection technique of DNA signposts which allows the identification of differences in the nucleotide sequences of the DNA in different individuals. Agriculture: a tool which allows crop geneticists and breeders to locate on a plant chromosome the genes for a trait of interest. It is considered more efficient than conventional breeding as it has the potential to greatly reduce development times and substitutes laboratory selection for much of the fieldwork. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: molecular marker

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: amount of organic material synthesised by organisms from inorganic substrata in a given area in a given period.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: primary production

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the intended catch of a fishery. (Opposite: bycatch)
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: target species

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: see: alien species.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: exotic species

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: any material of plant, animal, microbial or other origin containing functional units of heredity. [CBD]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: genetic material

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - a crop cultivar or animal breed that evolved with and has been genetically improved by traditional agriculturalists, but has not been influenced by modern breeding practices. [GBA] - farmer-developed cultivars of crop plants which are adapted to local environmental conditions. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: landrace

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: Agenda 21 is the framework for activity into the 21st century addressing the combined issues of environment protections and fair and equitable development for all. Agenda 21 provides a specific framework for many aspects of the UNEP programme. The agenda comprises 40 chapters each addressing specific aspects of these issues. See also: UNCED Rio Earth Summit.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: Agenda 21 from the UN Conference on Environment and Development
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.objecttrans_en: Agenda 21 from the UN Conference on Environment and Development
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.objectname_en: agenda 21 from the un conference on environment and development

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the named classification unit (e.g. Panthera tigris, Panthera, Felidae, Carnivora or Mammalia) to which individuals, or sets of species, are assigned. Lower taxa are  those at subspecies and species level (e.g. Panthera tigris sumatrae). Higher taxa are those above the species level (at genus, family, order, class, etc. level; e.g. Panthera, Felidae, Carnivora, Mammalia). [JVG]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: taxon (pl. taxa)

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the Conference of the Parties and its subsidiary bodies normally permit accredited observers to attend their meetings. Observers include the United Nations and its specialised agencies, non-Party states, representatives of other conventions, and other qualified governmental and non-governmental organisations.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: observer

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a facility designed for the ex-situ conservation of individual plant samples through seed preservation and storage.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: seed bank

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the modification of the genetic characteristics of a micro-organism, plant or animal by inserting a modified gene or a gene from another variety or species. GMOs may be micro-organisms designed for use as biopesticides or seeds that have been altered genetically to give a plant better disease resistance or growth. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: genetically modified organism (GMO)

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - one of several alternatives of a gene. - any of the different versions of a gene occupying a particular locus (place) on a chromosome. - one of two or more forms of a gene arising by mutation and occupying the same relative position (locus) on homologous chromosomes. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: allele

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the total amount of genetic material within a freely interbreeding population at a given time.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: gene pool

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: complex of traits related to reproduction and survival of the individual in a particular production environment. Adaptation traits contribute to individual fitness and to the evolution of animal genetic resources. By definition, these traits are also important to the ability of the animal genetic resource to be sustained in the production environment [FAO]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: adaptation traits

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: Popularly known as the 'Earth Summit', the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development (UNCED) held on 3-14 June 1992, in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, marked the twentieth anniversary of the United Nations Conference on the Human Environment held in Stockholm, Sweden, in 1972. Virtually every country in the world was represented (178) and more than 100 heads of state attended. The participating world leaders signed five major instruments: The Rio Declaration (a statement of principles); Agenda 21 (a framework for activity into the 21st century addressing the combined issues of environment protections and fair and equitable development for all, and includes the creation of a new Commission for Sustainable Development); a Framework Convention on Climate Change; a Framework Convention on Biological Diversity; and a Statement of Principles on Forests.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: Earth Summit, Rio de Janeiro

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the opportunity cost faced by an individual agent of using a resource (not including any externalities.) [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: private opportunity cost

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the primary healthcare for 20% of the world's population, the system of medicine developed over thousands of years in China, which treats the patient holistically, and includes herbal preparations - usually combinations of between five and ten species. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: traditional Chinese medicine (TCM)

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: speciation via populations with overlapping geographic ranges.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: sympatric speciation

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: unit building block of DNA. It consists of a sugar and phosphate backbone with a base attached.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: nucleotide

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - the diversity of genes within and among populations of a species. This is the lowest level of biological diversity. - variation in the genetic composition of individuals within or among species; the heritable genetic variation within and among populations.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: genetic diversity

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: any release of GMOs which is not a deliberate release [BSWG/2/5: UNEP Expert Panel IV Report]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: unintended release

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a non-profit group or association organized outside of institutionalized political structures to realize particular social objectives (such as environmental protection) or serve particular constituencies (such as indigenous peoples). NGO activities range from research, information distribution, training, local organization, and community service to legal advocacy, lobbying for legislative change, and civil disobedience. NGO's range in size from small groups within a particular community to huge membership groups with a national or international scope. [UNEP] Many relevant NGOs attend the biodiversity meetings as observers in order to interact with delegates and press and provide information. NGOs must be non-profit and can include environmental groups, research institutions, business groups, and associations of urban and local governments.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: non-governmental organization (NGO)

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the outcome of an action is said to involve risk where: the set of all possible outcomes of that action is known, and where the probability distribution of all possible outcomes is also known. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: risk

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: foods that are considered to have a positive beneficial effect on health, by the addition of active ingredients, or by making bioavailable existing ingredients. Includes 'functional' modified or fortified soft drinks and other beverages, bread, dairy products, cereals, and snacks. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: functional foods

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a storage facility where germplasm is stored in the form of seeds, pollen, embryos, semen, pollen, or in vitro culture, or in cryogenic storage, or, in the case of a field gene bank, as plants growing in the field. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: gene-bank

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: clusters of closely related species and subspecies that have evolved relatively recently.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: neoendemics

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: fertilised ovum of animal or plant formed from the fusion of male and female gametes.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: zygote

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: selective breeding, carried out by humans, to produce a desired evolutionary response.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: artificial selection

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: living on or in the bottom (in contrast to pelagic).
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: benthic

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a book listing, with descriptions and illustrations, all plants that grow in a given area. [JVG]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: Flora

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the death of any lineages of organisms. Extinction can be local, (when it is known as extirpation) in which one population of a given species vanishes while others survive elsewhere, or total, in which all its populations vanish. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: extinction

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: an evaluation of the likely impact on biological diversity of proposed programmes, policies, or projects. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: impact assessment

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a territory defined by a combination of biological, social, and geographic criteria, rather than geopolitical considerations; generally, a system of related, interconnected ecosystems. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: bioregion

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: reddish-brown discoloring of surface water from blooming populations of dinoflagellate phytoplankton; since long associated with nutrient pollution.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: red tide

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: any incident involving a significant and unintended release of genetically modified microorganisms in the course of their contained use which could present an immediate or delayed hazard to human heath and the environment. [Council Directive 90/219/EEC on the contained use of genetically modified microorganisms]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: accident (accidental)

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - all the genes of a particular organism or species. - the complete set of genes and non-coding sequences present in each cell of an organism, or the genes in a complete haploid set of chromosomes of a particular organism. [FAO] - the genetic endowment of an organism. When expressed, this will result in the observable characteristics or phenotype. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: genome

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: non-living; devoid of life.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: abiotic

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: organisms into which DNA from another genotype are introduced by, for example, micro-injection or retroviral infection. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: transgenic

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: suppression, containment or eradication of a pest population [FAO bis]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: control

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: The Montpellier Declaration on the Cartagena Protocol on Biosafety.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: Montpellier Declaration

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: crop forms developed from landraces. Improvement through selection restricted to a few specific characteristics and often more uniform in nature than a landrace. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: primitive cultivar

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a breed where the total number of breeding females is between 100 and 1,000 or the total number of breeding males is less than or equal to 20 and greater than five; or the overall population size is close to, but slightly above 100 and increasing and the percentage of pure-bred females is above 80 percent; or the overall population size is close to, but slightly above 1,000 and decreasing and the percentage of pure-bred females is below 80 percent. [FAO]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: endangered breed

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: any breed that may become extinct if the factors causing its decline in numbers are not eliminated or mitigated. Breeds may be in danger of becoming extinct for a variety of reasons. Risk of extinction may result from, inter alia, low population size; direct and indirect impacts of policy at the farm, country or international levels; lack of proper breed organization; or lack of adaptation to market demands. Breeds are categorized as to their risk status on the basis of, inter alia, the actual numbers of male and / or female breeding individuals and the percentage of pure-bred females. FAO has established categories of risk status: critical, endangered, critical-maintained, endangered-maintained, and not at risk. [FAO]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: breed at risk

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: prices generated through a market mechanism. When all costs and benefits (societal) have not been taken into account, this may be less than the social cost. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: market prices

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: see: 'Earth Summit', Rio de Janeiro.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: Rio Earth Summit

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the potential value of the resource for future (direct or indirect) use.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: option value

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: accumulation of unnatural concentrations of certain chemical compounds.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: chemicalization

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: companies which combine businesses in pharmaceutical, agricultural chemicals and products, and food and nutrition. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: life sciences companies

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: any recognizable trait, feature, or property of an organism.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: character

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: places in the world where crops have the greatest genetic diversity in the form of traditional crop and varieties and/or wild relatives. Centers of diversity are typically, but not always, the same locations as the centers of origin or oldest cultivation of the crop. [BSWG/2/5: UNIDO BINAS Website: Biotechnology Library: Perils amidst the promise: glossary]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: centers of origin and diversity

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the appraisal of a investment project which includes all social and financial costs and benefits accruing to the project. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: cost-benefit analysis

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: occupying different geographical ranges. (Opp.: sympatric.)
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: allopatric

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: fundamental units of basic inventory information that are crucial for biodiversity conservation planning and management. These are both biotic and abiotic and usually include: (1) the presence and/or abundance of species and other units; (2) other dependent biotic data (e.g. plant cover for macroarthropods); (3) the appropriate influential abiotic variables, and (4) human variables. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: baseline data

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - an area particularly rich in total numbers of species. - an area of especially high pollutant concentration.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: hotspot

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: advanced germplasm in a breeding or crop improvement programme. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: elite

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: occurring in the same place. (Opp.: allopatric.)
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: sympatric

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the ability of a given assemblage of organisms to withstand disturbance without a major change in the number of species or individuals.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: stability

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: readily observable features of vegetation that are considered significant for growth, physiology and survival (for example pollination mechanisms, seed dispersal mechanisms, rooting systems.) [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: plant functional attributes

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the recovery of specific ecosystem services in a degraded ecosystem or habitat.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: ecosystem rehabilitation

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the genetic engineering of plants to produce sterile seeds. It is considered the most morally offensive application of agricultural biotechnology, because over 1.4 billion people depend on farm-saved seeds. See also: traitor technology.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: terminator technology

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: see  zooxanthellae.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: algal symbiont

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: incidental take; also called non-target species.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: bycatch

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: study of the way plants, animals and micro-organisms are used by humans.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: ethnobiology

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: chemical reactions in plants and plant-like organisms whereby the sun's energy is absorbed by the green pigment chlorophyll, permitting carbon dioxide and water to be synthesized into carbohydrates accompanied by the release of water and oxygen.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: photosynthesis

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: bioprospecting seen as the means to a new 'green petroleum', capable of bringing wealth to the gene-rich, but financially poor countries of the South  (ref.: K. ten Kate, 1995. Biopiracy or Green Petroleum? Expectations & Best Practice in Bioprospecting. - Overseas Development Administration, Environment Policy Department, London).
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: green petroleum

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - individual having two copies of the same allele at a genetic locus. - individual having two identical alleles of a particular gene or genes, and so breeding true for the corresponding characteristics. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: homozygote or homozygous

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: 'a carrier'. In genetic manipulation the vehicle by which DNA is transferred from one cell to another. An agent of transmission; for example, a DNA vector is a self-replicating segment of DNA that transmits genetic information from one cell or organism to another. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: vector

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a protocol is linked to an existing convention, but it is a separate and additional agreement that must be signed and ratified by the Parties to the convention. Protocols typically expand or strengthen a convention by adding new or more detailed commitments. [JVG]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: protocol

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the sum of use and non-use values with due consideration of any trade-offs or mutually exclusive uses or functions of the resource/habitat in question. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: total economic value

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - a species whose loss from an ecosystem would cause a greater than average change in other species populations or ecosystem processes; species that have a disproportionately large effect on other species in a community. [GBA] - a species that influences the ecological composition, structure, or functioning of its community far more than its abundance would suggest.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: keystone species

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - the largest yield that can be obtained which does not deplete or damage natural resources irreparably and which leaves the environment in good order for future generations. [GBA] - the maximum amount of a species or group of species that can be taken without diminishing the future take.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: maximum sustainable yield

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a substance used to cause a reaction, especially to detect another substance.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: reagent

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - the genetic contribution to future generations; the average number of descendants. - the expected contribution of an allele, genotype, or phenotype to future generations. The fitness of genes and organisms is always relative to the other genes and organisms that are present in the same population. Usually it is measured as the average number of offspring produced by individuals with a certain genotype, relative to the number produced by other genotypes. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: fitness

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: breeding and rearing fish, shellfish, etc., or growing plants for food in special ponds. [GBA]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: aquaculture

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: refers to all human activities including strategies, plans, policies and actions undertaken to ensure that the diversity of farm animal genetic resources is being maintained to contribute to food and agricultural production and productivity, now and in the future. [FAO]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: conservation of farm animal genetic resources
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.objecttrans_en: conservation of farm animal genetic resources
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.objectname_en: conservation of farm animal genetic resources

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: still living at the present time. (Opposite: extinct)
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: extant

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the determination of the activity or concentration of a chemical by its effect on the growth of an organism under experimental conditions. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: bioassay

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: radiation beyond the violet (high energy) end of the visible light spectrum. UV-B is the middle range wave-length of the three UV bands, and is largely absorbed in the Earth's atmospheric ozone layer; prolonged exposure to UV-B can be biologically damaging.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: ultraviolet radiation

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - a technique in which portions of a plant or animal are grown on an artificial culture medium. (Also: in vitro culture.) - in vitro methods of propagating cells from animal or plant tissue. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: tissue culture

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: a forest largely undisturbed by human activities. (Also: natural forest; opp. secondary forest.)
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: primary forest

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: suggests that the number of species increases or decreases depending on how the environment influences species production, exchange and extinction at any particular time.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: non-equilibrium theory

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: - any technological application that uses biological systems, living organisms, or derivatives thereof, to make or modify products or processes for specific use. [CBD] - any technology that is applied to living organisms to make them more valuable to people.
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: biotechnology

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: agent that induces a mutation within an organism, such as X-rays, gamma rays, neutrons, and certain chemicals such as carcinogens. KP is an agent capable of inducing a mutation (a change that alters the sequence or chemistry of bases in the DNA molecule) in the genetic material of an organism. [CUB]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: mutagen

biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.definition: the spectrum of genetic differences within each breed, and across all breeds within each domestic animal species, together with the species differences; all of which are available for the sustainable intensification of food and agriculture production. [FAO]
biodiversity-chm.eea.europa.eu_nyglossar.name: domestic animal diversity (DAD)
